147058218.review:
A trilogy of humorous point and click adventures, featuring Deponia, Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia.

[hr][/hr]
The Deponia series takes place on the eponymous planet, which consists mostly of junk, scrap and garbage and follows Rufus, an egocentric and not too capable inhabitant, on his quest to leave the planet and reach Elysium, an elusive city floating in the clouds. The games feature a large cast of creative characters as well as a variety of diverse locations, which keeps things fresh and interesting throughout.

The games’ story is certainly interesting and will keep you playing, delivering twists and turns as well as a good amount of character development, but where the series really shines is with its humour. Dialogue is witty and Rufus has something to say about just about everything, with jokes often featuring dark comedy and setting the protagonist up to somehow be both likeable and a massive jerk.

You’ll find the games to be classic point and click adventures, having you talk to characters, explore locations to find objects and somehow combine everything to solve light puzzles in order to progress. The Puzzles are well-explained and logical enough to be beatable by just about anyone. Should you ever get stuck, there’s a highlighting feature to mark all interactable spots and the option to skip any minigame.

The drawn assets and cutscenes look great and are complemented by great voice acting (I used the original German dub.) and a fitting, memorable soundtrack. Throughout the games Deponia feels like an actual place, with many unique locations and characters giving it a lived-in atmosphere.

This collection also has some unique features not found in the individual games. You’ll have access to a world map showing your progress, a quest log for even more guidance through your tasks and a developer commentary, offering insight and original songs for every single screen in the game. The first game also contains new collectibles strewn throughout it, like the sequels already offered.

[hr][/hr]
This is one of my favourite game series and I very much recommend getting it. You’ll have a bunch of fun.

Feel free to take a look at my reviews for the individual games for a bit more insight on them.

I've played a few point and click adventures over the years, my favourite being the curse of monkey island. And while I wouldn't consider myself a great puzzle gamer, I know what i like and what puzzles I enjoy. The Deponia games I did not enjoy. 

Don't get me wrong, a lot of love and attention to detail has been poured into these games. The visuals, the story, the characters (despite the main character being highly annoying), and the atmosphere are all fantastic. But it's the puzzles that really let it down. They simply aren't logical. There's one puzzle that requires you to turn down the music in the settings to progress. I don't remember there being a prompt to do so, unless part of the dialogue is lost in translation. The hints towards some of these counter intuitive puzzles are so vague or easily glossed over it'll have you googling a walk-through. In fact I challenge anyone to play the English language version and complete all three games without using a guide.

Another annoyance about the puzzles for me is the strange way they're often dragged out into multiple parts. For example you might need to combine part A with part B to make something work, but combining them broke both parts and now you need to locate parts X Y and Z to fix parts A and B and then take them to another location to have them altered in some way before returning to finally use parts A and B to complete the puzzle. All the while none of this process will be obvious within the context of the game. For me, when the solution clicks and I figure it out, that's where I get my dopamine hit. In this example, locating and combining parts A and B is a puzzle enough in itself if done properly. It's where the whole point of playing a puzzle game comes from. For the game to then stick it's finger up at you and say sure you got that part right, but now that puzzle has changed and there's more for you to do, really spoils it. It feels like the over-engineering Germans are infamous for bleeding into the puzzles. And as for the humour, well it's typically German and no laughing matter.

142691404.review:
Let me preface this by saying, I really didn't want to do this. Daedalic is (well, was) an outstanding developer of point-and-click adventures, having produced some of my most beloved games, like The Night of The Rabbit, The Whispered World, or Anna's Quest. (You should try those!) One of their most prestigious titles, the Deponia series, sadly doesn't live up to that reputation.
I would probably rate the first installment positively, but from then on it just gets gradually worse. Let me explain:

1. The Plot
Is there even a linear plot? Sure, Rufus and Goal -> Elysium. But that mission becomes entangled in so many setbacks and plottwists that it's just a whole giant mess. I know I should stop comparing everything to monkey island, but it's just a too perfect example for a point-and-click game. The main goal there is usually separated into a smaller set of goals, (originally: find a ship, crew, and navigator to sail to monkey island!), each of those still requiring lots of tiniest puzzles to be completed. But at least you know what you're working towards, and at which stage you're progressing. Deponia in that sense is entirely unpredictable. Once you think you've acquired something, it's taken from you, or you're transported to a different environment, changing the course of action entirely. It makes the story so jumbled up that I couldn't retell it if I tried, and at the end, I had no clue what  was even happening. 3 Cletusses? Why? I'm very lost.

2. Gameplay!
Safe to say it is a decent game of its genre, in terms of mechanics. I didn't get bored playing through it, at least. Mildly frustrated at most. Some puzzles are oddly counterintuitive, and it takes some research at times. Maybe you could blame it on the chosen universe, which is entirely unknown to the player, thus causing some confusion as to how things react with each other. Again, more familiar universes, like pirates and monkey island- you have an idea of what to expect. I won't say it's a bad thing that they made up their own world with unique rules, solutions just tend to feel a bit arbitrary at times. And then the minigames- I'm usually a person who tries, but I gave up at the last part. Most of them are really just clicking around until you get lucky.
However, I was lucky enough to not encounter a single bug during my playthrough, but I've heard otherwise, so be aware of that.

3. The Protagonist
I could've easily looked past the previous parts, if only the entire game weren't so flawed in its essence. I believe the whole point was to parody usual adventure games, where a girl to be rescued only serves as a 'Goal' and the protagonist will use everyone in his way to achieve this. While it might be a common trope, the way to counter this is not to write the exact same thing in a blatantly exaggerated fashion. Rufus is simply insufferable. (Even more so with his German voice, which seems to be an ongoing issue with Daedalic... just listen to Sadwick in The Whispered World... this led me to play the game in English despite being German, but I believe the jokes were transported well; it felt very natural.)
The game makes you play a selfish, outright cruel character, and forces you to follow his ideas. It doesn't feel like you're helping the hero on his adventure, you're just responsible for him getting his way. Point-and-click protagonists are usually snarky and careless, but not insulting in every line of dialogue. It's really unpleasant to watch, and might've been worth it had there been a change of some sorts- but no, every time you expect him to make some progress, it only gets worse, throughout the entire series. No, I don't want to kill those baby dolphins. I don't want to be a piece of shit to some orphans. But the story just goes that way, and it's not for the sake of a joke, just unnecessary. Rufus is written in a way that makes you hate him, maybe on purpose, but they didn't seem to realize that this doesn't make for an enjoyable game.

4. The Big Issue
So, this game likes to make jokes. Some that go way too far, objectively. Quite every touchy subject one could think of is joked about here: racism, sexism, pedophilia, transsexuality, domestic abuse, suicide and mental illness, just to name a few... 
You can make good jokes about all of those. Remember that skin color/difficulty slider in the second South Park game? Yeah, that was funny. Know what's not funny? Making a black person very literally play the monkey. I probably would've thought this is a joke had I heard about it before, it's just so blatant and wrong I don't even have words. Multiple things make it worse: it's the ONLY black character in the entire series, she is directly and explicitly addressed as a monkey, and drawn in an almost-nude, overly sexualized fashion. There's no joke to it, this is supposed to be the whole joke. It's beyond me how any company could regard this as remotely okay, even in 2013.
This thing connects to the entire underlying sexism the games have going on- frequently, the female leads are drawn in extremely seductive poses for no reason, and if you find collectibles in the second one, you get a literal nude drawing of Goal as a reward. I can almost see the illustrators salivating every time a female character shows up.
This whole display of femininity in an overly sexual way is awful to see throughout the entire series. If this was meant to be a critique of said thing- you don't make a parody by showing the exact same, but worse. Anyone remember the movie 'Cuties'? Yeah, that's what they did too, and it backfired big time.

Other jokes are borderline-inappropriate but still well done. I chuckled at the rope vendor. I feel the game had some good moments, but turned increasingly unappealing. Of course it's not badly made by any means, but it leaves me wondering how some of these jokes made it to the public. I can usually look past lots of bad design choices, but the broad use of themes that are simply inexcusable prevent me from giving an overall positive review. Should you play it - sure you can, it's not terrible gameplay-wise. Just be aware of everything mentioned above; it might leave you with a bad aftertaste. Oh, and I almost forgot something: (spoilers ahead)

5. The Ending
[spoiler]Ah yes, that ending. I had read plenty about how bad it supposedly was, so it didn't shock me quite as much. I have to agree though, that was the most unsatisfying experience, given I had already subjected myself to everything mentioned above. With how cluttered that plot was, a constant up and down, it didn't even matter a whole lot to me. But from a storytelling perspective- killing off the main character for no reason, really? 
This can be done well in a story that builds up to it, which this one didn't. It seemed like an entirely arbitrary decision, just to make things even more messy. They tried to fix that general dissatisfaction by simply providing an alternate timeline in the spin-off, but, that's part of a different review. See you over there then.[/spoiler]

Deponia: The Complete Journey is a compilation of the Deponia games: Deponia, Chaos in Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia. Thirdly, the puzzles are quite challenging and thankfully give some advantages if you need them to complete the game; they are mainly new puzzles, making each of them quite defiant overall. Lastly, the story was quite criticised, but it was actually fantastic; the whole evolution of the plot and the character development were perfect; the problem is that it is not for everyone. [*][h3]Negatives[/h3]

[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]

Lavishly illustrated and animated, professionally voiced, rich with content, and made with obvious passion for the genre. Piles of puzzles, some quite intricate, are linked into splendidly tangled webs. As a fan of point-and-click adventures, I found the production polish and the flashes of brilliance so compelling that I played through the whole thing.

That said, I can't recommend it. It's too lacking in taste, in every sense of the word. 

The characters and storyline, the comedy, the dialogue, the puzzle cluing, even the music and the artwork — everything is always slightly misjudged (or worse), and it all adds up to be much less charming and engaging than it thinks. I felt mildly annoyed the whole time, and kept wondering "Is it me?" "Is it because it's German?" "Is it because the translation isn't quite right?" I'm still not sure, but I'm inclined to just blame the creators. The lead designer inserts himself onscreen at every chapter break, as a "funny" balladeer who belts out ridiculously-wordy-but-that's-the-joke lyrics about the action, in clumsy convoluted English that apparently felt playful to a German but is just exasperating for a native speaker. This is emblematic of the whole [i]Deponia[/i] experience: bombastic self-indulgent insular dorkiness. If that's your speed you might love these games. It's not my speed.

This series has taken a lot of flak for having a despicable player character, and for invoking sexist and racist stereotypes in a queasy way, and for other offenses against decency. Well yes, and it can indeed be quite off-putting. But it's important to note that all these things were done deliberately, with would-be satirical intent. The protagonist's outrageous selfishness is obviously meant as a comment on the amorality of player behavior in most adventure games; calling the female object of desire "Goal" and giving her a programmable brain is obviously meant as a spoof of lazy sexist tropes. Etcetera. The trouble is that the tone isn't controlled confidently or purposefully enough. I've seen jokes about all these same tropes in other games where it was much clearer what was the butt of the joke and what wasn't. [i]Deponia[/i] is so sloppy and sophomoric that it seems to want the player to laugh at the ugliness [i]and[/i] with it, at the same time. I didn't laugh much at all.

It's a shame because there are some really good bits — some genuinely inspired puzzles and setpieces that were tantalizing enough to keep me playing, despite my irritation. But it's just too big a haystack to recommend the needles. There's a lot of game here! I took 25 hours to get through the whole trilogy, but I was impatiently speed-reading the dialogue and skipping the audio; it's easily 30+ hours if you play at the intended pace. 

Don't!

Allow me to start off by stating that this review will contain some spoilers. But I will try to keep them as mitigated as possible. 

Firstly, I will state that this game has a beautiful mixture of wit, dark humor, actual regular humor, and even puns in the writing. There was hardly ever a moment where I did not laugh in an uproar of jubilation. Whether it be from the karmic moments of things biting various characters in the bum, or the various unhinged and inane methods of illogical problem solving that Rufus was written to have.

Second, I would like to state that the music for this game is superb, even the music used for bits that are meant to be comedic are so good that you likely still hum the tunes when you finish this game series. The writers clearly understood the notion of how music can both enhance and diminish the impact of a scene.

Thirdly, I would like to state that the actual story of the series is superb. While it can be a bit difficult to follow at times between the constant laughter you will be going through, it is hands down up there in my list of games with monumentally well done stories. The moments of romance, tragedy, and drama are all there. And they are done to such an extent that I would personally recommend this game to any person who enjoys a rich narrative with wonderful world building.

The art style of the game is also something that I have come to greatly adore. Every scene, panel, item, and character are superbly made. Each one has their own flair of design that makes them memorable. This is both in their design and their character personalities. It is a shame that games like this are far and few between that make me enjoy the traditional story telling elements in it.

Oh, and before I forget, there are some jokes that are indeed lost in translation from the German version. Which I only was able to understand due to my learning the language in college. But if you do understand German, do yourself a huge favor and play it with the German audio or subtitles enabled. Because they are absolutely hilarious.

Finally, I would to say that the true canon ending shows the most development for the character, and though it makes me a bit sad that it is indeed the true ending, I am also happy at the same time in some manner. While I wish things were happily ever after, true stories, like in life, are seldom ever truly happy. There are middle grounds that are seen.

In summation, I would say that I would rate the game in the following categories.

Music: 9/10 There are times that the music, even though it is superb, can be a bit hit or miss. But that is not at the fault of the game, but the listener.

Art style: 10/10 It is colorful when it needs to be, and dingy when it needs to be.

Story: 9/10 While I would have preferred a happier ending, I find the only true fault to the story is that between the constant laughter of situations, or the occasional frustration over some of the puzzles, it is woinderful.

Game play: 7/10 Despite being a point and click game, the playing is fun, engaging and entertaining. The only issues lie in the nature of point and click games themselves. You have to adapt yourself to the thinking of the creators at times for some of their strange problem solving methods. 

Total: 8.75 I would highly suggest this game to any individual who enjoys humor, world building, and overall good fun.

122279306.review:
I want to start off with saying that I know that I'm in a minority here. Deponia is a game that is very well liked, and I will say that aside from a couple of problems, the adventure game mechanics are solid in the whole series. It's clear from the level of detail and quality of animations that there is a lot of care poured into this journey, and I always feel a little bad when I leave a negative review for games like this. However, I really didn't like this game, and I want to share why. So here we go.

Let's start with the mechanical problems I alluded to above. The setting of Deponia is one of its strengths, being original, well thought out and functional as a critique on society. However, having a setting full of garbage means that visual clutter is an issue and the common genre problem of moon logic (i.e. contrived puzzle solutions) becomes that much worse. The solutions are in fact zany enough that it's close to impossible to figure out what to find and how to use it on your own, especially at the start of the game. A highlight button and hint system are present and does some to alleviate the situation, but it leads to a reliance on these systems that is still to the game's detriment. So, when interacting with the world becomes scaled down to pressing the highlight button and using the hint system to understand what to do (if that even helps), why have such a detailed world in the first place? Isn't the point to have players be rewarded for exploring and thinking about the world, instead of forcing them to only highlight the useful stuff?

The second problem I have is with animations. There are puzzles in this game that require you to watch long animation sequences over, and over, and over again. You can skip them, but as clues to the solution are often given in those cut scenes, you're heavily disincentivised from doing so. Compare it to something like Monkey Island, where cut scenes are given as a reward instead. In Monkey Island, that leads to memorable scenes like the manor fight-behind-the-wall that sticks with you as a unique experience; in Deponia, the same type of sequence quickly gets old because you've seen it five times over and have had to wait for it to play out every time in order to get to the part where the clue is given. To add to that, the animations can be oddly mistimed and badly paced, with several seconds passing by as a small animation plays out way slower than it should. The game simply drags, which peeled away at my motivation to play the game until only stubbornness remained.

These problems are minor, even if they are impactful, but they're not the reason why I'm giving a negative review. No, what left me thoroughly soured on the whole experience is the story and the humour of the game. Deponia sports an intentionally unlikable protagonist, Rufus, and I can understand why. It's supposed to be a parody on point-and-click games, who often have leading characters that are disruptive to society because things need to be forced to happen. So here we have a lead who pushes this to the extreme and is severely disliked for it. Cool.

What I don't understand is why the game has to be so unpleasant to play as a result. I think that Rufus' solutions to problems are supposed to be callous by design, since he's a narcissist and all. The problem is that you, as a player, are forced to do things that aren't just callous, but cruel. All the while, it's played as if it's a joke, something that is supposed to be funny. You feed your friends urinal cakes, you blow up their homes, you cause accidents that leads to them being hurt, sometimes Rufus actively chooses to hurt them. People die in this game as a direct result of your actions, people that you've talked to and gotten to know, and it's played out as a punchline. And somehow we're still supposed to root for Rufus, because even through all the lampshading about his behaviour the game throws at you, it still defends him. He's still the hero, he's still the one who strives to save the world and who supposedly cares about the people around him. And at the end, when Rufus is supposed to prove himself to be reformed, I simply felt resentment.

Furthermore, I have to question what the developers felt they could get away with because of Rufus' bad character, and what they consider funny. The jokes in Deponia seems to largely be about Rufus being the worst human possible, but the punchline is often the people who get hurt, not Rufus himself. Haha, look at that loud-singing gondolier being eaten alive by crabs, isn't it funny? Haha, Rufus killed and tortured a parrot through his incompetence, isn't that hilarious? Haha, Rufus sold the only black character as a slave, isn't it...? The rampant sexism (complete with breast jiggle animations!), the low-key racism, the disregard for people's worth (especially when they're poor), the implication that Rufus' friends just need to get over their dislike of his behaviour and accept him for who he is... Now consider this coming up in a meeting, where someone seriously said "Let's animate one of the women being caught in the shower, that'll be good". It's extremely sleazy and I can't help but wonder if Rufus being an unlikable character is just an excuse.

I really didn't like this game. It was a chore to play through, it was uncomfortable to take part in and I wish I hadn't picked it up in the first place. While I can recognize some of the craft, the art and the effort going into Deponia, I can't recommend it. There are other adventure games that are far better, in my opinion. If any of the things I brought up resonates with you, then I recommend that you don't play this game.

I dabble in quite a few genres, with adventure games being one of them. In terms of gameplay mechanics, they don't mesh well with my tastes, but I still sometimes seek them because of the promise of a good story. The best of them tend to have one which makes up for what I find to be tedious gameplay overall. Of the ones I have finished, I thought these were worth my time to varying degrees:

The Blackwell series
The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav (and Memoria)
The Dream Machine
The Edna & Harvey series
Farenheit: Indigo Prophecy
Grim Fandango
Hector: Badge of Carnage
Jolly Rover
Landlord of the Woods
Leisure Suit Larry 6 - Shape Up Or Slip Out
Life is Strange
Lost Horizon
Lydia
MacGuffin's Curse
Midnight Scenes: The Nanny
To the Moon
Night In The Woods
The Shivah

Of the [b]Daedalic Entertainment[/b] games I have played (including the [i]Edna & Harvey[/i] series, [i]The Whispered World[/i] and [i]A New Beginning[/i]), I found the Deponia trilogy to be the least enjoyable. 

As with previous Daedalic titles, the backgrounds are aesthetically pleasing (if a little too busy in some areas) and the music is mostly excellent. Some tracks evoke a sense of 'grand adventure', which I felt at times might have been a better fit for a different game altogether. It's too bad that playing through this trilogy felt more like a tired exercise than anything else.

I think that it's pretty normal to expect point-and-click adventure games to involve puzzles which are not straightforward and require one to think like the designers did ('moon logic'). In the case of Deponia, this is really all that I had left to amuse myself with, as I didn't find the story interesting. It's also worth mentioning that there are some bugs which require using a downloaded save from Daedalic's website in case you are unable to progress past certain puzzles.

The main character, Rufus is selfish and mostly oblivious to the needs of others. There isn't really anything more to him, but I somehow expected this. The problem is that the other characters in this game aren't very interesting either. For example, the other major character, Goal (interesting choice of name by the way), is out of action for almost two thirds of the series for various reasons despite being on-screen and physically present in some form or another. 

The other characters who accompany Rufus don't seem to serve much purpose other than to act as a foil. They were present for much of the trilogy. Despite some moments in the third game, I found them to be under-developed overall.

I think that this might just be the way it is with most comedic adventure games. However, the problem here is that I didn't find the trilogy to be all that funny. For what it's worth, German voice acting and English text was enabled because I thought the voice actor for Rufus was better suited to the character. There's no doubt that some puns and such may have been lost in translation, but I think most of the humour is still easily understood because much of it involves moments of schadenfreude. 

Some jokes are at Rufus' expense, but I found there to be an inordinate number of situations where the developers seemed to have gone to great lengths to set me up for a laugh at someone who didn't really deserve their misery or misfortune. There seems to be thread running throughout the series: we the audience are meant to find humour in how clueless Rufus is about the consequences of his actions on others. 

Given the contrivances in the setup of many puzzles, it is too much of a stretch for me to find Rufus' obliviousness plausible. Perhaps it might have worked if he had a severe mental disability, and I do mean the drooling, pants-on-head, talking-like-a-Monty-Python-Gumby variety. That would probably necessitate a total rewrite of just about everything though. Suffice it to say, humour involving uncertainty about the protagonist's awareness of what is actually going on around them was better handled in a previous Daedalic title. I think it worked better in [i]Edna & Harvey: Harvey's New Eyes[/i], due to a combination Lilli's apparent childish innocence and the narrator.

Despite all of this, I forged on anyway. As I had little emotional investment in all of the characters, the ending was not very satisfying, and leaves me doubtful as to whether the fourth entry, [i]Deponia Doomsday[/i], will redeem it in my eyes (I hear it's a safe to skip that one). There seems to be a bit of a trend at [b]Daedalic Entertainment[/b]. Either it looks as though the writer wrote themselves into a corner, it ends up all being just a dream or a major character gets shafted big-time. More often than not, I don't think they manage to stick the landing in their games.

This one's probably for the hardcore point-and-click people who really like running around exhausting dialogue options and rubbing objects together. Not for me though, unfortunately.

120461641.review:
Normally I don't review games without having beaten them or at least experiencing the majority of the content. However after encountering a game-breaking bug after seven hours of play and the only solution is to restart. I feel I have strong enough opinions to review this product. While there are three games here, they are all part of one larger story. With only getting through almost all of the first game before encountering the game-breaking bug my words are only about the first third of the product.

In addition to the mentioned game-breaking bug (for those of you who know it is a minebike puzzle where the levers don't work and entering the mine has the minebike disappear and the game will not respond to any further keyboard or mouse input), the game also has several technical issues that show a lack of polish. Clicking on objects in your inventory sometimes doesn't select them. There are typos and words that are untranslated from German. There is also one character's voice audio that is mixed terribly. It sounds like their microphone as they were shouting their hammy villain lines.

Enough of the technical stuff, what kind of game is Deponia anyway? Deponia is a point and click adventure game that asks the question "What if Monkey Island was bad?" (Yes Monkey Island fans, I know that franchise has its black sheep but I'm speaking generally.) It's quite clear that the developers are fans of those old point and click games but fans of the genre in such a way that they uncritically copy and paste mechanics that should have stayed in the past. For example, elaborate inventory puzzles. You are given a 5x5 grid of an inventory and you are gonna be expected to make use of a lot of that space. Collect every bit of garbage you see and then spend plenty of time trying to combine two items that should go together until you realize you need a third thing in the overworld to do so. While game doesn't have the worst moon logic, there are bouts where you will be hauling around about a dozen objects trying to use each one an every other item in your inventory and every bit of the environment to drive progress forward. On the difficulty of how to do things, there's a certain point where I gave up trying to solve some of these puzzles and relied on a guide to get through some of the weirder or more finicky parts of puzzle design. There's a lot of back-and-forth between rooms and screens that feels like it was bordering on padding. A lot of the minigames also have balancing issues of either being too simple or too complex.

As for the story and characters, I feel this is where Deponia has a mixed bag. The main character, Rufus, clearly is inspired by Guybrush Threepwood from Monkey Island by being self-absorbed and being in way over his head. This is fine for the most part but becomes a problem once the main love introduced. There are some interesting character designs such as Gizmo that stand out for being creative. The planet of Deponia being comprised of trash and the city of Kuvaq are interesting settings that. Aside from a few good character designs and an interesting setting, the story and remaining characters are not very enjoyable. This might be because I'm less than one-third through the complete package so I will be a bit lighter in my criticism where appropriate regarding the plot. There is a floating ship/city thing that Rufus wants to escape to and when he finishes the prologue by making an attempt he overhears a conversation between a woman and an obviously evil authority figure. The woman plummets planetside and he chooses to save her. Pretty generic player character rescues princess plot.

From what I know of Monkey Island there's a similarity between Elaine and Deponia's love interest in that they're both conveniently written out of the plot for most of the game and don't have to interact with the protagonist. This game does it by way of an electronic Sleeping Beauty which means Rufus is tasked with lugging a barely alive body around for a good chunk of the game. I've been referring to this character not by name and that's because the devs didn't bother giving her one. Waking her up is Rufus' goal so she is literally named Goal.

Talking about Goal brings us to the issue of female representation in this game. From what I remember of my playtime there are three female characters with speaking roles and only one is any kind of decent. The first is Rufus' ex-girlfriend who he mooches off of by living in her house, eating her food, not doing any chores, and constantly annoying. She's the best of the female characters for actually having a decent bit of dialogue and out of my sympathy for her having to deal with the protagonist's antics despite breaking up. The second female character is Goal, a character so generically the damsel in distress that a plot point is that when she falls down into Kuvaq a line forms of horny desperate men who can claim her and take care of her while she is unconscious. This is in spite of the town having a doctor and at least one hospital bed. Rufus is the worst of these because he believes that because he saw her first he is entitled to be the romantic interest of some woman he has just met. It is very possessive and creepy behavior from not just our protagonist but most of the men in the town. Our third female character is the mayor's receptionist. This character has two "gags." The first one is being the bureaucratic obstacle that Rufus has to overcome to advance the plot. The second "gag" is being trans and having the voice actor swap between speaking in falsetto and gruff shouting. It fills her lines with false starts and repetitions which means being told to wait in line takes about twice as long. It was not funny back in 2012 when the original released and has only gotten worse with time.

To summarize, while Deponia has a couple of interesting ideas, those are buried under incompetence in game design, story and character writing, translation, sound design, user interface, and coding. There are far better point and click games around and this one can be forgotten.

118981560.review:
Deponia: The Complete Journey is a trilogy of old-school style point and click adventure games. The games are honestly not bad, but I can only recommend them to people who are already fans of this niche genre. Anyone else will simply be frustrated and bored by this series. The "humor" is often purposefully repulsive. I had to force myself to finish the games and then made the mistake of getting all the achievements. To put it bluntly, the achievements will make you hate the game if you didn't already.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Story [/h1]

The story is quite honestly mediocre. The main character, Rufus, is intentionally written as an insufferable, misogynist prick. The game makes a feeble attempt to play this off as part of Rufus' charm, but he really is just a sexist jerk that thinks the world revolves around him. He gets slightly better and his personality is somewhat explained in Deponia 3, but it doesn't change the fact that you have to endure his presence for the whole series.

With the exception of the ending, Deponia 1 is a complete slog to play through. I almost quit the game because of the glacial story progression and having to listen to Rufus in Deponia 1. In retrospect, I definitely should have. The story in Deponia 2 is an improvement which makes it tolerable to play despite Rufus still existing. The story in Deponia 3 is easily the best of the 3, but once again, Rufus is still Rufus (albeit slightly improved).

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay is very much in line with other games of this genre. You point and click to move around, pick up items, and talk to people. There is a basic inventory where you can select items to use or combine. Numerous minigames are spread throughout the story progression and usually take the form of some kind of puzzle. The minigames are skippable, but most of them aren't too difficult. A very simple hint system gives you pointers on what to do next.

The main problem with the gameplay is that it often turns into trial and error. Progression is needlessly convoluted to make you "think". Even when I knew exactly what I was supposed to accomplish, I still found myself spamming every single item on every interactable object to find the right combination. There were many instances where the correct combination didn't make sense to me even after it worked. If I wanted to "think" and solve actual puzzles, I would just play SpaceChem (one of my all time favorite puzzle games).

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Achievements [/h1]

[b] Please, for the love of god, IGNORE THE ACHIEVEMENTS [/b]. They do not add value to the game, you will not enjoy unlocking them, and any enjoyment you might have will be ruined by them. During Deponia 2, I noticed that I was naturally unlocking a lot of the achievements, and I decided to try to get 100% achievement completion (a huge mistake). I finished the game with around 85 of the 105 achievements, so I looked up guides to get the last 20 (an even worse mistake). What followed was a soul crushing, massive waste of time.

Achievements in this game usually boil down to doing X thing Y times, finding an easter egg, doing something in a certain order, or simply progressing the story. These are the easy achievements that you will find naturally. [b] The difficult achievements will require you to strictly follow a walkthrough guide. [/b] They are not fun or satisfying to complete. An even smaller subset of these achievements will unlock bonus content, but they are not worth the time and effort. [b] It is possible to mess up and have to replay multiple chapters to try again. [/b] Seriously, just look up the content online and save yourself the trouble.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

• Only play this game if you already enjoy old-school point and click games.
• Yes, Rufus sucks. He only gets marginally better.
• Sexism, transphobia, and racism are part of the "humor".
• Ignore all the achievements. Attempting to get them all will ruin the game for you.

The story is pretty good and keeps you interested, even if there are a few sections which are just storyless busywork. Now, the game will not be for everyone: the main character is a huge asshole 98% of the time, very hard to actually like, but that is obviously by design -- many jokes are made at his expense. Some of the humor is quite improper, so to speak, especially in the 3rd part. And a few puzzles were too hard and nonsensical for me (especially in the 1st part -- the difficulty level was a lot fairer in the last 2 games).

But, all in all, a great game that was sitting for 7 years in my backlog!

Score: 82/100.

[b]I've changed this to a "recommend", simply because I think putting Deponia Doomsday at a "not recommend" brings the Deponia series as a whole to a "meh" rating. This game has a lot to like despite it all, even if I still wish I never played it. Everything below this bold text is unchanged from my original review.[/b]

It's really hard for me to give a rating to this game. It's been three years since I played it, and it's still very hard.

[b]Deponia: The Complete Journey[/b] is a collection of the three games [b]Deponia[/b], [b]Chaos on Deponia[/b], and [b]Goodbye Deponia[/b].
It is a point and click adventure starring Rufus, a guy trying to reach the flying utopia Elysium. Early on he meets Goal, a girl from Elysium whom he instantly falls in love with. The goal (haha) from there on is to reach Elysium with Goal, something that is usually hindered in some way.

Why is it hard to rate this game? Because there's a lot here to like. The setting, the characters (with one important exception, elaborated on below) and the journey are all really good. The puzzles are zany, not overly difficult (with one sole exception in the second game, lol), and do not involve moon logic. The art style is great and the music is servicable.

Why then did I, in the end, decide to give it a thumbs down?

There are 3 main reasons:

[b]Reason 1: Rufus[/b]

Rufus is an unlikeable asshole that, while sometimes entertaining, is rude to everyone he meets and doesn't even think twice before sacrificing someone for his personal gain. He has his moments, but even then it's doing something right for the wrong reasons. The game and the characters in it do not excuse him in any way, with many characters, some initially and some later, expressing their hatred of Rufus and how he's made their lives miserable. The whole reason the plot in the second game happens is because of his inability to control his selfish urges. In other words, it's not enjoyable to play as this character. Many puzzles had me sighing while I realized that the game expected me to do something outright cruel in order to advance. I understand it's supposed to be funny, but to me it was anything but.

[b]Reason 2: The ending[/b]

If you've played this game and you've read this far you might be wondering why I dislike the ending. It's really hard to talk about without spoiling a whole lot, but basically the ending might be satisfying for the characters (I'd still claim it's not), but not for the player.
I realize this sounds interesting, but with all things combined: you're forced to play as this narcissistic douchebag, to reach an ending that disappoints you.

[b]Reason 3: The creator's response to the fans regarding the ending[/b]

The creator knows about the split reaction to the ending and does not care. While integrity in creative works is good, this guy went out of his way to mock people who disliked the ending by creating the sequel Deponia Doomsday. Read my review of that if you want to know more.

In summary there's a lot to like, but when I think back on this game and the time I spent with it, my only wish is that I hadn't bothered.

In the end that's the worst feeling you can give someone. No strong feelings. Just that it was a waste of time.

101596445.review:
Deponia: The Complete Journey is a trilogy composed by: Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia, which is currently the best way to play them in the correct order and also includes some extras like devs commentary.

The first game is a great introduction to Rufus, our comedic hero, and his crazy colorful world. The story of Deponia is clearly its strongest point, filled with a great sense of humor reminiscent of LucasArts golden era. Narrative cleverly breaks the fourth wall, with characters sometimes realizing they are part of a game and funny moments that might get you to chuckle. There are multiple twists along the journey and it’s always hard to predict what is going to happen, also thanks to Rufus unpredictable actions. As a classic point-and-click graphic adventure, the game requires you to explore different areas, talk to characters and solve puzzles, combining items and figuring out how to complete certain actions. Puzzles are generally good, but rely too much on comedic ways of solving rather than rational thinking. There are some hints you can get by talking to certain characters, but it’s disappointing solving puzzles only to realize the solution didn’t make any sense. Mini-games, on the contrary, are entirely different, requiring some logic. Luckily, there is a skip option if you can’t solve them and only want to progress with the story, so it's very accessible to those who are new to the genre.

Chaos on Deponia, which is my favorite, expands the gameplay by offering a sandbox environment and open narrative. There is a great sense of progression and it feels more like you are visiting a wonderful connected world rather than solving puzzles around smaller separate areas. Puzzles seem to be easier, relying more on logic than casually combining items in the inventory looking for unexpected solutions. There are still a few ones that can be tedious to deal with, but I appreciate the general improvements on the UI and hints given by other characters. Rufus himself has gone through a major change. He still retains his humoristic traits, but now his childish and selfish attitude have been replaced with more heroic and mature values. So, instead of simply being a more of the same, Chaos on Deponia fixes almost all its prequel problems, offering a more appealing and cohesive adventure. Characters show signs of growing and the comedic tones finally reveal some sparks of drama. Puzzles have been refined and now follow logic more than absurdity.

Then Goodbye Deponia arrives and destroys everything. While the story is generally good (although maybe too dark), there are undoubtedly some huge mistakes in the writing department. Whereas in the prequel Rufus was finally getting a more defined characterization leaving behind his childish nature for a more mature behavior, here he actually degrades to a clown who constantly recycles his jokes. There were some really disgusting moments where Rufus humor went pretty much over the line, such as sending children towards a pedophile to pet his “hairy animal” (which is exactly what you think) and selling a black woman into slavery calling her a monkey. I doubt anyone could laugh at these disturbing moments; on the contrary it’s highly possible feeling offended. The other serious problem is that Goodbye Deponia ending leaves an unexpected sour taste. What should have been a rewarding conclusion to the “complete journey” is rather an unsatisfying epilogue that refuses to give any answer to the player. During the ending credits you will keep wondering what happened to all those characters you encountered and loved through all the three games, hoping for a secret ending scene that will never arrive. This is greatly disappointing and will probably upset many players who can only hope for Deponia Doomsday to deliver a proper ending.

While not perfect, I still recommend this (in)complete journey. If you love graphic adventure games and steampunk enviroments, then Deponia will be a fascinating world to explore, but keep in mind that puzzles often don't follow any logic and the ending could easily be one of the worst you've ever seen in a video game.

100681450.review:
Yes, yes, yes, yes!

Deponia is the culmination of Daedalics greatest minds in a unified effort to deliver a tale of heroics, daring and dastardly deeds, egotism, and all the ups and downs that ones personal journey of discovery and awareness may bring. 

Deponia stands as Daedalics greatest light-hearted title to date, a story of how ones aspirations will not only change his inner self, but how they directly impact the world around him, manipulate the relationships of his peers and friends, and bend time and space continuum (literally). The Complete Journey is a trilogy of the three main narrative entries, being Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia. 

Deponia is a fantastic entry to the series and is honestly one of its best ones, even despite its awfully short duration. As the initial platform in which we boost ourselves off into the stratosphere, it's undoubtedly one of the most sturdy in introducing us to the wacky and wild world that Rufus - our main hero - inhabits. Great puzzle design, great character introduction, albeit short, but a very sweet game.

Then along comes Chaos on Deponia, and whilst arguably, maybe not the best entry to the trilogy, its easily the most broad and expansive. Though its first act very much overstays its welcome, it eventually opens itself up to smaller sections which hit user satisfaction in greater rapidity. Intertwined and laced amongst its more boisterous and bold moments are some of the more quiet and reflective ones, and its in this episode we strike the best balance, save for the repetitive scenery we grow all too accustomed to. 

And finally, Goodbye Deponia, the greatest of all three. A true return to form very reminiscent of the classic that began it all, with a great variety of stages with a huge variety of puzzles to wrack and wrap your mind around. We're exposed to a higher production quality along with some brand new toys and mechanics to play with. 

As a trio, these games are honestly excellent. The art-style is truly iconic, its some of Daedelics best work as it blends simplistic character design with intrinsic and highly detailed environments. I could argue all of Daedelics styles are fantastic, but Deponia really sets itself from the rest in just how well it all interconnects and synergises. 

The humour, although admittedly childish at times, has some absolute stand out moments, with most of them being prominent in the third game. Despite this, a good deal of humour is sewn into the dialogue and cleverly helps to reflect the deep and complex personalities that populate the junk-world that was our once beloved green Earth. It's never so in your face to truly drag you out of the experience, and in fact most of it blends seamlessly into the entertaining interactions between the characters.

As for said characters, they're some of the best work these games have on display. Every single dialogue interaction is absolutely worth listening to, as the ultimately jovial and comical nature of the game draws you in effortlessly.

The puzzles are superbly laid out, granted some are absolutely mind warping, to the nth degree, but when you realise that a great deal of the puzzles solutions are finely hinted at through its narration, the way you approach the riddle changes entirely. 

Deponia is a masterwork of all the facets of a great puzzle-adventure game with an enjoyable and entertaining narrative to boot. I honestly could not recommend it more. Even for all its faults, such as an overly frustrating inventory - which seems to need more mouse clicks than necessary - its a game that comes shining through. Easily one of the most memorable games I have played in recent memory, and if you are a fan of the point-and-click puzzle-adventure genre, this a game that absolutely deserves to grace your collection. 

Huzzah - good things come in threes!

Deponia follows the misadventures of Rufus on his journey to escape the trash dump of a planet he calls home and reach Elysium the beautiful utopia which floats above Deponia. Rufus is an asshole, like a massive asshole. While he often saves the day in the end, he always leaves a trail of destruction on the way. The humor of Deponia comes from Rufus, whether its him acting stupid, selfish or just down right horrible, that's where it comes from. If you can't deal with playing as a character like that, then you might not be able to finish the game, you might feel just that guilty. Trust me though, the jokes are incredibly funny and the overall plot is great with an amazing ending.

In terms of game play Rufus's character works amazingly, no longer will you ask why the fuck the main character is stealing and hurting people just for the sake of some absurd puzzle, because well... it's Rufus, he has 2 brain cells what did you expect.
 
The game can be quite hard, but luckily has a good checklist to keep track of goals, a hint system, and the ability to skip any minigame(though I suggest playing them yourself). If you are still stuck and are ready to look up a walkthrough try this instead: https://www.nicegamehints.com/guide/deponia/
This hint website provides hints to push you in the right direction and will even give you full answers if the hint isn't enough.

Here are guides for the next 2 games: https://www.nicegamehints.com/guide/chaos-on-deponia/ https://www.nicegamehints.com/guide/goodbye-deponia/

All in all you should definitely get this game and its well worth its price as it includes the entire trilogy. If you're still a bit on the fence about buying it then I'd wait for a sale.

He steals [i](well, that one is on me I guess, you need items for point-and-click-games, okay?)[/i], he lies, he cheats, he uses other people as a means to an end, deceives them,  he's only looking to further his own goals... what are his goals? To get to Elysium. You see, Rufus is stuck on a planet called "Deponia", and he has dreams to reach the magical city in the sky... literally, actually.

Several unfortunately accidents later, Rufus has made a mess of things and now needs to try to fix the situation. The best example of this is the simple task "remove dust from memory card", How would YOU remove dust? carefully wipe it down with soft cloth, use a safe spray? What are you stupid? No, clearly the first you need use a dirty towel to make it gross, then to spit on it, brush it with a metal brush to leave permanent scratches, and then plug it back in. Did you flinch? I flinched, And that's the whole game more or less... Rufus makes bad situations worse.

So here we are again... Rufus is an interesting character. But I HATE him. Does he have any redeemable qualities? At the end of the story he makes the right choice... But the end doesn't justify the means.

Let's get really philosophical for a second, If you push someone in front of a car to save a family, you've still killed someone. Rufus is worse, he'd push someone in front of a train to pick up a quarter on the ground, then search for spare change in the pockets of the disemboweled legs, and proceed to buy something from the other half of the dying person with the money from his/her own legs.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2503956399

[b]Gameplay:[/b] A "Point and Click" game should be simple to explain from a mechanical standpoint... It's right there in the genre title... You play this game with a mouse, you point the cursor, and click.

There is an inventory, you mouse wheel down to access it. The first rule of point and click games is: "Pick up all the things", the next rule is "Talk to and inspect all the things, all chat options".
From there you ****SHOULD***** Have alllllll you need to figure out the puzzles, and know which item goes where, and figure out what you need. [i](Pro tip: hold down space bar to see all intractable objects. I couldn't have made it without you space bar!)[/i]
Deponia: The Complete Journey even does you one more, with a sketch outline from Rufus giving you hints and reminders what your goal is, and the step you're on for reaching that goal.

But, of course Point and Click Games eventually require you to do crazy stuff... for example to open a door you might need to use a waffle with a pigeon , to make a fat pigeon which you can use with a hairbrush to make a slip stream pigeon missile that you'll shoot out of a cannon at a switch on the other side of the world.
How would you know the pigeon was the key? Because some character commented "Boy I sure  do love pigeons and would hate to know my pigeon was shot into next Monday"... Only think more cryptically then even that. 

For a real example: [spoiler]One puzzle required me to turn the music off in the game settings... WHAT?! Who does that!? But it was clever. ...also I never would have finished the first third of the first game if I hadn't looked up a guide there!! [/spoiler]

I would like to highlight a couple other things before wrapping up this review: The graphics were great. The world was interesting. I cared about the love interest. I liked the side characters and was happy every time one of them popped up again. The animation is very good. The music was good. The musical narration after each chapter was my favorite part "Huzza lets come back for more!", there were a few mini-game-puzzles I did actually enjoy, I even chuckled at some points and references in the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2492033263

[b]Conclusion:[/b] The question I pose to myself is this: Did I like the game? 
...I can't just give a straight "yes" or "no", there are things I liked and things I disliked. Generally I think I'd lean in the positive direction. There was a lot of work put together to make this game, I picked up my copy for free somewhere, it also regularly goes on sale...

It took me a surprising amount of time to finish the game even with the help from guides, in each section I always tried to figure out what to do on my own first until I hit a dead end and looked it up. The first part took me 7 hours, The second part took me 10 hours, The third and final part took me 10 more hours. Ending with a grand total of 27 hours.

I think the worst thing a game can be is "forgettable". I heard that point and click games are where the unique stories in video games are at. While my opinion on Deponia: The Complete Journey is certainly mixed, I can confidently say it was an experience I won't soon forget. Some people will like this game, others will hate it. Sorry I can't really help much more then that.

95045497.review:
[h1] One Man's Trash... [/h1]

Deponia is a point-and-click adventure game about the world's most unlikable protagonist, Rufus, and his quest to get the hell off his Godforsaken trash planet (No, really - the entire planet is more or less a giant landfill.) and reach the fabled land of Elysium. He's selfish, self-obsessed, and completely fails to develop as a person over THREE games, and yet somehow wasn't a completely unlikable character. His saving grace, I suppose, that he occasionally helps out other people - though never without promise of reward. 

But I'll stop talking about Rufus now. God knows you'll hear him talk about himself more than enough over the course of the game. Let's talk about the game itself.

The gameplay in Deponia is, as far as I can tell, fairly standard for a game of this genre. I haven't played a ton of point-and-clicks, but you sure do point, and you sure do click. The various puzzles this game offers walk a thin line between absurdly clever and extremely frustrating, but there are a number of quality of life features (I.e Options to skip minigames or highlight interactable items in a room) that make the experience notably less anger-inducing. Aside from basic combining-object puzzles, there are various minigames as well, and they're at worst inoffensive, sometimes outright fun. 

[h1] ...is another man's treasure [The Good] [/h1]

What really makes Deponia shine is its world and sense of humour. I just love the artstyle - reminds me of some old French comic I can't remember the name of, and the world being essentially a run-down landfill makes for some unique locations. Most of the main characters (and even some side-characters) are pretty memorable, and you can't help liking (or at least feeling sorry for) them for having to deal with Rufus and the frustrating, ridiculous (and often deadly) situations he gets them in all the time. As with any 30-hour adventure, not every joke is a knee-slapper, but my playthrough was filled with more laughs and chortles than groans and, uh, more offended groans. Also, each chapter starts with a funny little ditty about the events of the story so far, which helps reduce tension is some more frustrating sections.

[h1][i] Sometimes it's just trash, though.[/i] [The bad] [/h1]

...how many times have I said frustrating now? Probably not enough. If there's any reason that you'll drop this game, it's from frustration. I'm not saying you'll need to use a guide throughout the entire game, but sometimes the items you're expected to combine, or actions you're supposed to take are so ridiculous that entire scenario feels like some piece of absurdist comedy or abstract art that can only be comprehended if you throw your brain out the window. Furthermore, there are a few glitches, though fortunately most I have encountered in my own playthrough were harmless and often amusing. One of my friends did, however, lose his entire savefile through no fault of his own - thankfully, this particular issue seems pretty rare. 

[h1] I've run out of trash puns [Conclusion] [/h1]

I'd say I'd recommend this collection - but then again, I bought it for 90% off during a summer sale a couple years back. Maybe don't wait for that big of a sale, but don't buy it at full price either.

[b] 75%, B [/b]

Edit:
...Forgot about that dang racist monkey joke. Whoever put that in there, screw you. Nearly dropped the game after that, but came back out of desire to see the end of the story. There's dark humour and then there's stuff that wouldn't even have been acceptable half a century ago. I'm not going to change the score (because if I did, I'd give this game an F on that alone) but I am leaving this edit here as a disclaimer for anyone looking at this game.

This is a streamlined combination of the first three Deponia games, including optional developer commentary, a bunch of artwork and the third soundtrack. While I think it's worth full price, it's almost perpetually on sale for 90% off, so just wait a literal week if needed.

I will warn you that the game has a few issues (see below) - most notably that the first game is buggy and especially non-intuitive. I almost refunded it at one point, but had exceeded the maximum playtime (because of a literal game-breaking bug). Be sure to stick it out, as things (mostly) improve after a while.

Also, the Store page saying there's 40 hours in the game is a lie. I got probably 30 out of it (which is a lot from a P&C game), not including paused time. I probably spent 5+ hours being stuck and too stubborn to look up a guide (three times, I think) for a hint on the next step.

Note that this is NOT a children's game in terms of some crude humor, language, human and animal cruelty, and a few bits of softcore pornography (if you're into women with no noses anyway...though, you're not looking at the faces, are you?).

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Colorful and well-animated, including cutscenes.

+Good music, and comes with soundtrack to the third game.

+Voice acting is great and has no translation issues (I'm looking at you, A New Beginning).

+Humorous, with plenty of genuine LOLs.

+Fast travel, object highlights and puzzle skips.

+You can't really die, and you can try all the dialog options in nearly every conversation. This allows you to explore all the voice acting and absurd possibilities available.

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Your character is a bit of a (loveable) jerk for most of the game. There's some development and explanation as the game progresses, though.

~Contains mostly-slapstick cruelty to animals, women, children and well, everyone, really.

~Main menu music sounds like it's for another game.

~Missable achievements.

~The ending isn't horrible as everyone says. But, to avoid spoilers, it leaves a lot to your imagination.

~For as much fun as is poked at Daedelic's [i]A New Beginning[/i] game, it was generally good at providing intuitive item descriptions and puzzle solutions. Deponia much more frequently relies on the old "try everything with everything" routine that wasn't fun in the 80s and 90s and isn't fun now. I'm going to suggest keeping a guide handy for when you start getting frustrated. Besides the first game, you usually know what your goal is, but the path to getting there borders on moon logic on occasion. I skipped two puzzles out of pure spite of the trial and error involved.

~The game often gives you a number of major objectives, letting you tackle them in somewhat open-ended order, but also leading to some more confusion in too many choices for the "try everything on everything" routine.

~Occasional minor textual translation and spelling issues (voices are fine).

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-The first game (from 2016!) is still buggy: sliding characters, broken music, getting stuck in inspect mode and the pigeon puzzle occasionally is 100% broken, requiring you to download a save file from Daedelic to continue. Further, it has obtuse and guesswork puzzles. This is a really bad start to the game and I think puts a lot of people off, unfortunately.

-Tooltips in menus, puzzle hints and "map/plan" screen only occasionally fully work.

-Majority of puzzles in the third game start suddenly and don't allow you to back out. If you need to take a break at that time, you're forced to to solve or skip the puzzle, or ALT+F4 and hope you saved recently.

-You won't even know about, or find the optional bonus collectibles in the second and third game without a guide to get you started.

It’s got all the charm of old point & click adventure games—the characters are weird and irreverent, the puzzles are obtuse in a way that can make them funny, the art and animations are immersive, and the areas you visit are scenic and full of character. It's great to see a relatively modern (as in, within the past 10 years) adventure game carrying on the legacy of the genre.

Unfortunately, it goes too far in some of those places. As many other people complain, the main character is often just annoying. You have to learn early on not to try to relate to him or be concerned for him, because he ruins everything for everyone around him. Rufus is like a force of nature, and you have to treat him that way. Don’t pray that he “does the right thing this time”—he’s capricious and unpredictable. Just enjoy the spectacle from afar. Even then, though, he can be REALLY annoying.

In a similar vein, it’s annoying how the plot can be artificially drawn out by Rufus’s shenanigans. Especially in the third game, certain long puzzle segments only exist because of problems Rufus created himself. It messes with the flow of the game; you’re interested in finding out where the story is going, but then you have to spend an hour on busywork to fix something that was working just fine until Rufus broke it.

Some of the puzzle solutions are funny, but the sense of “oh come on what am I supposed to do” can rob you of the enjoyment. I highly recommend using a guide when you get stuck for more than 10 minutes, unless you’re really committed to having the classic adventure game experience. The story, characters, and the environments are good parts of the game that are still fully enjoyable without spending hours being stuck because you couldn’t figure out you had to combine two silly items together. Considering this is three games in one, you’ll likely appreciate the faster pace that a guide brings, so that you aren’t spending 100 hours on this trilogy.

Still, as long as you don't let the puzzles wear you out and upset you (by using a guide when you've tried everything you can think of), and you don't try to use Rufus as a self-insert character, the good outweighs the bad. The writing, while off in places (like anything regarding Goal's attitude toward Rufus), is fun and well-paced. The English voice acting is fantastic, which is surprising given that the developers are German, and the art style, animations, cutscenes, and locales are great. Make no mistake though—while the story is fun, it's not necessarily [i]good[/i]. It's mostly intentionally silly, which makes some of the serious scenes fail to elicit any response from the reader; especially when Rufus ruins them.

Note: if you run the game at a refresh rate above 60 Hz (like if you have a 144 Hz monitor), you’ll have trouble clicking items in your inventory—most of your clicks won’t register, and you’ll have to click 2+ times to select an item. You can fix this by setting your monitor’s refresh rate to 60 Hz. This problem is fixed in the fourth game, Deponia Doomsday.

[h2]setting[/h2]
Meet Rufus: the most selfish, lowest of the lowest procrastinator of Deponia! He has a plan to leave Deponia, heading for Elysium! That's because Deponia is made of literal junk, while Elysium is a mythical heaven! A long journey through Deponia awaits. Rufus meets many memorable characters along the way, visits many fantastical trashy places, and maybe evolves into a caring gentleman?? 

[h2]a trilogy is born [/h2]
Early in the development it became clear that this story is too big for one game, so it was decided to cut it into three games of average length. There are times where part of the games feel slightly stretched, but overall they did a very good job. There is almost no recycling of scenes (I can only think of small scenes at the transitions of the games). These are exactly the games [i] Deponia, Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia. [/i] As a bonus, the lead developer recorded extended commentary of every scene in this game! 

[h2]oh Rufus... [/h2]
Rufus just isn't very likeable... At least, at start. This is a very specific type of comedy, in which you only identify with the protagonist with your very worst traits. This isn't everyone's jam. Nearly every negative review of this game has a problem with this aspect. One could simply state to 'plow through', but I think that it's better to acknowledge that we're all different. 

[h2]my [strike]junk[/strike] thoughts [/h2]
The drawings are beautiful. There is a lot of imagination in the art, sort of steampunky. It looks like chaotic junk, at the same time carefully orchestrated. The voice acting perhaps deserves even more praise! The music is okay, but at times a bit bad, so I turned it off. The opening song is really good, and it gives the game a fantastic start! Thankfully the song bridges every chapter, with appropriate lyrics. 

The game is not easy, it requires some Point & Click smarts, and even then it's hard. Every game's story is about 15h long, so it totals around 45h. That's a huge amount for a P&C. This is probably not the best entry to this genre. That said, I do fully recommend playing this game. There are in-depth walkthroughs available that try not to spoil things. 

[91/100]

74453939.review:
Deponia: The Complete Journey is a trilogy packed point & click adventure type game that is full of great storytelling, fun and witty remarks, nice artstyle and many other things that it has to offer. However, at the same time it's really hard to recommend this game to everyone as it is definitely not made, nor marketed for every type of player. Here are a few pointers.

[h1] The story [/h1]

(For those who wish to skip any part of the game story (MINOR SPOILERS IN THIS SECTION), you can skip this section whatsoever). The trilogy of Deponia follows the story of Ruffus - a mad-type egoistic inventor who's main target is to get out of Deponia - a junkyard of a planet - and get to the Elysium - a spaceship that is set for utopia. Throughout the games, however, you find yourself not only trying to get onto Elysium, but you are also set with a new goal to save Deponia from destruction by joining and spreading the word of a rebellion, finding new love and even somewhat solving conflicts with your inner self. This game is really nothing to scoff about when talking about storytelling - it has a lot to offer and can pull you straight in. It's like reading an extraordinary post-apocalyptic/fantasy type of work (or watching one at that matter) - an intriguing and interesting beginning, amusing character conflicts and a culmination that lets the player's imagination decide what really happened at the end. If you're looking for a great story in a game, then this alone is a good argument to try the game out!

[h1] The gameplay [/h1]

As mentioned before, this is a point and click type of game. And at first this might make the game sound boring. But on the contrary. While it's true that you'll be using your mouse alone for the entirety of the game, the puzzles and the sections of the game is where it really shines. 

To get through the sections in the game, you will have to interact with various objects in the world, take them, combine them, generally speaking - use them to your advantage. The same goes with other characters (NPC's) of the game  - you have to either talk them into doing your bidding for your 'master' plan or trick them so that they would do something useful for you. At first, this all sounds quite understandable and easy, but some sections are either really long and confusing or really tricky to get a grasp of. Ruffus thinks differently than everyone else in Deponia (as he likes to call himself – being a total genius misunderstood by others). Thinking differently means that everyday tasks will have to be done in a completely different manner (one that a normal person would never think of), and the objects that usually have a use for a specific task will be used differently as well. And this is where the gameplay is vastly different from most point and click adventure type games - by using the same mechanics differently this game doesn't feel stale, the format doesn't seem overused and it actually makes you think. I love a really good puzzle, and i have to say that this game can be called a one huge puzzle that unravels beautifully as the story goes on.

The game also has some minigames - these are more focused to either get a specific object or to finish a specific task. Some of them are easy, some of them are quite hard, some - not as interesting. The good thing is that this concept is not overused by that much, which means that you don't get tired of it as easily.

The game also has a bunch of achievements. You may think 'big deal, most games do'. And you'd be right. But this game in particular has plenty of hidden achievements that are easy to miss. That either means that you have to check everything in this game, try out the most unusual combos, or just replay again the second time. In other words, this game has quite a bit to offer.

[h1] The graphics [/h1]

The trilogy of Deponia looks, feels and plays out like a cartoon. You will find yourself surrounded by clustered, colourful towns, roads, alleyways, etc. The world is quite detailed, so much so that sometimes it is hard to find for what you're looking for (luckily, there's a tool that highlights with which objects and (or) NPC's you can interact). The game has a unique look - a one that you can memorize quite easily and tell apart from others. To put it simply - the world is vibrant and beautiful, gives inspiration to creating your own post-apocalyptic world.

My only concern sometimes (and this is nitpicking) is that the framerate of the animations (or perhaps - the animation itself) usually feels a bit choppy, stutter like. It's most likely a choice for design by the developers, but personally i'm used to a smoother animation experience. 

[h1] The sounds [/h1]

Throughout the game you will hear various soundtracks, and most of them are unique to each area. Is that background music memorable? No, not really, but it does help to feel more immersed into the game.

What I really enjoyed throughout the games were these short animated music clips where throughout a short song the narrator tells the story which you're currently exploring, followed by a chorus. The songs are wacky and sometimes do feel like they're improvised, but they're fun to listen to. Whenever you hear a "Huzzah!" at the end, you know that you're playing Deponia! 

And the Organon hymn that you can listen to fully in the last game (and is played as the main menu song in the first game) can really please your ears! 

[h1] Various bugs, glitches, etc. [/h1]

Never encountered any of the sort. However, i have read in some guides and forums that some people do tend to lose their save files (or they get corrupted) if they save during a very specific event or while being in a specific location (sometimes - the combination of both). What i would suggest doing is just having a backup save in your extra save slot for 'just in case' situations.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

So, back to the main question - is this game worth trying? Yes, absolutely! If you love adventure type point and click games with plenty of brain teasers, amazing storytelling and interesting dialogues, this game is definitely for you! The full trilogy can offer around 20+ hours of gameplay (depending on how easy you can catch onto the puzzles, if you use any sort of guides, etc.). On the other hand, if you enjoy a more action-packed and fast paced games, i would recommend skipping this title whatsoever as it is not what you're most likely looking for. This is a much more relaxing type of game that can pull you in for hours without the feel of being forced to rush.

Masterpiece of an adventure game, full of absolutely hilarious moments that will either get you laughing or crying as the story goes. As I was playing the game, I couldn't wait for the story to progress and see what will happen next. I will try to keep this review spoiler free.

[b]About the game:[/b] Deponia is a 2D Point & Click adventure, that is delivered like an interactive cartoon. Puzzles range from basic, to an insane difficulty, but that's good. The game will force you to think a lot!

[b]Story:[/b] Story is where this game shines. In short, it is a story of an antihero that has big dreams, and you need to help him to achieve them. The characters are really well designed and you will like most of them. Rufus, the main character, can be at first a bit annoying to an extent, but as the game progresses you will learn to like him.
One thing that I don't like about the story is the ending. I see that players are split into two groups, they either love the ending or hate it. I fall into later group, but I sort of understand what they wanted to achieve with it.

[b]Graphics:[/b] The art style is beautiful! Everything in this game is all hand drawn scenery, and animations. I personally prefer 2D Point & Click adventures over 3D. 2D style will give a cartoon style, so it's more entertaining in my opinion.

[b]Music:[/b] Soundtrack is also a masterpiece. Soundtrack is influenced with Hip-Hop beats, US country style music, etc. You will be presented with a Huzzah guy at every chapter of the game. I believe that all Huzzah songs are sung by one of the Daedalic members named Poki.

[b]Verdict:[/b] This is a game that you absolutely must play, especially if you like story driven adventure games. Even if that's not your cup of tea, I highly recommend it. Game is a pure 10/10!

Now I really have to praise Daedalic. Daedalic is such a talented game studio, currently my favorite game studio (or for last 8 years or so... 🤣). I can't wait for more Point & Click games from Daedalic. They haven't released lately any, so I hope they didn't abandoned the genre. Much love for Daedalic!!!
