70340305.review:
[b]Disclaimer:[/b] I did not finish all chapters in Deponia's "The Complete Journey" and stopped playing after 11 hours for reasons listed below. I wanted to like this game and  gave it a fair try with 10+ hours played.

[+] Great graphics
[+] Great (English) voice actors
[+] Optional developer commentary

[-] Sexist, racist and LGBTQ-phobic humour
[-] Unlikable protagonist
[-] Varying puzzle difficulty/logic

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]
Deponia looks good and in the 11 hours I spent with it, it also played well. The difficulty for a point-and-click adventure is medium to advanced and I rarely got completely stuck. That being said, by the time I stopped playing, the riddles became more abstract and less enjoyable. The by far biggest problem in this game which eventually soured the entire experience and fun so much was not even the very unlikable character, but the strong sexist undertones in this game. I still kept playing, hoping that strong sarcasm or some other redeeming factor would eventually appear, putting everything into context, but it never happened. 11 hours in, the protagonist is just as unlikable as before and the game still gives me the impression that it was written in the 1950s. While playing, I wondered if it's just me who sees a problem here, but after doing some brief online research, it became very quickly clear that I'm by far not the only one who questions the writers' decisions.

I grew up with the old classic Lucasfilm Games/LucasArts point-and-click adventure games and was more than happy to see that this game genre was coming back to life again with many new titles worth playing, like Primordia, Thimbleweed Park, The Cat Lady, Shardlight or Technobabylon, just to name a few. And no matter if we are talking about the very first games in this genre (Maniac Mansion is from 1987, Zak McKracken from 1988, Monkey Island from 1990 !) or more modern adventure games, none of them ever gave me the uncomfortable feeling that Deponia gave me.

I'm familiar with anti-heroes in literature, movies or video games, and while Deponia's protagonist Rufus sometimes indeed makes a indeed a few (non-offensive) jokes that made me chuckle, his unlikable character traits always outweight these few positive moments. I enjoy dark humour and strong sarcasm (example: South Park), but the "edgy" jokes that Deponia apparently wants to make are just dull and lacking any sarcastic edge or criticising undertone, making it seem like the writers actually mean what they wrote and make fun of. This is often further enhanced by the protagonist's unlikable personality, which lacks any kind of self-aware sarcasm, making it seem that he actually believes in what he is saying and making fun of.

My initial impression and expectation with the game's sexist mentality and unlikable hero was that the hero's journey would be a story of character change or self-questioning. Likewise, I expected (or rather hoped) that the sexist undertones were handled in a much more sarcastic and self-aware way, highlighting that the damsel-in-distress formula has been outdated for a very long time -- and indeed, in all forms of media, this has been highlighted in clever and/or entertaining ways countless times. The main female character is not only called "Goal", she was during the 11 hours that played the game most of the time unconscious.

I'm purposely not getting into in-depth details, as many others already wrote lengthy details about Deponia's problems, and I recommend reading them too before buying this game. The game has also rightfully been criticised for making jokes at the expense of the LGBTQ community or animal abuse. From what I have read, Deponia also adds racist jokes to its list later on.

Maybe Deponia fixes the problems I mentioned down the road, yet it should not take me 11+ hours to get there. Also, based on the articles I read, the game apparently does not correct its tone and problems, but stays on its course and digs itself a deeper hole.

While the hand-drawn graphics of Deponia will age very well, its writing and humour won't.

The team behind this game cleary put a lot of effort and time into the Deponia saga. The game indeed looks great and the English voice acting is also good. Sadly, the game's writing ruined the game for me.

[h3]Rufus[/h3]
Deponia to me is the biggest, genre-defining discovery ever made. It has easily blown all other adventure games out of the water with its beauty and wits. It calls itself "a dramedy of error" and I agree, it fits the narrative. The games raised my standards sky high, some of the point & clicks I used to review positively in the past got lucky that I haven't played this by then. But let's not drag it out and talk about Rufus. Admittedly, he is not a good man... which doesn't stop him from being a great character! He's a rare breed - a flawed protagonist, an anti-hero who combines certain traits of Ash Williams, Woody Woodpecker and Roger Wilco into one hell of a destructive, narcissistic, yet charming personality.

Many people are unhappy with him, I think that a good portion of them hate him just because the games' NPCs do... don't be so gullible! And consider this: Deponia is a whole another world (you know, like Africa), growing up there wouldn't leave you with the same morals and attitude towards, say, death that you've got from floating through life in a bubble of our cultural civilization. Lay off, he's a crazy creature from a bizarre parallel universe, not your fucking desk neighbor. Besides, he's got some great qualities: carefree attitude, ingenuity and unwavering optimism, the things that perfectly replace mercy and common sense, at least in his world.

I don't deny that Rufus is an extremely controversial individual who doesn't hesitate when it comes to 'accidentally' killing children or baby dolphins. But he likes cats and platypuses, and let's face it - he doesn't show any pity to himself either! Makes him consistent and cool enough in my eyes. He also caused a couple of other non-issues that people with obnoxiously colored hair deem sexist (a bunch of intentionally childish, in-character jokes that aren't glorifying anything) or whatever... okay, I have to admit that [spoiler]selling a black woman to a jewish looking character for her to serve as a grinder monkey[/spoiler] was kinda insensi... hey, look, a vampire platypus! You missed it. Now, where was I? Ah, I was just about to inconspicuously move on to the next subject.

[h3]Story[/h3]
All of this wouldn't be worth a dime if the story our protagonist resides in wasn't any good. To be honest, judging by the looks, I expected something bland and family-friendly but was very surprised to encounter a plot so captivating, thought-out, bold and action-packed that it kept me extremely intrigued all the way through. The writer(s) evidently took lessons from many sci-fi books, shows and Douglas Adams's creations in particular. The story features cleverly written, eccentric and memorable characters, cheeky humor, unpredictable twists and a good portion of slapstick comedy. The world-building is spot-on, the dialogues are witty and never too wordy, the voice-acting is as good as it gets. It felt like I was playing through a cartoon version of some best-selling comedic novel. I'm yet to see how it ends, have Doomsday ahead of me, but I'm already a fan of the dystopian setting. As a bonus, there's a strong, unobtrusive environmental message featured among other things. And if you don't like something, don't care or just want to speed things up - you can always skip ANY dialogue and ANY animation at ANY time by hitting escape. That's quality of life for you.

[h3]Puzzles[/h3]
By the way, have you seen these games!? Of course, you did and I don't think that I need to tell you how gorgeous they look! And not only in static - the animation is also superb and got even better with each installation. So, let's skip drooling over the FANTASTIC graphics and jump straight to the puzzle design, which is even more astonishing, believe me. After the first game the developers greatly expanded the scale. The sequels take place in numerous locations at once, sometimes you even control more than one character. I usually don't like it, for it tends to make everything too convoluted, but Deponia is so smartly designed that I rarely felt lost. The games never get too overwhelming, they always give you only a moderate amount of hotspots and items that you need to deal with at once. 

Besides, Rufus draws schematics of his plans, so you always know your immediate goals and said schematics are also one of your hint sources, a part of the ingenious hint delivery system, which works, basically, through everything around you. Pay attention to the world, don't just click blindly through everything. In most cases, item descriptions and clues dropped by characters in dialogues are carefully set up as a joke where a puzzle's solution serves as a punchline. The puzzles use cartoon logic, yes, but it's good logic for clever puzzles supported by a clever hint system. And not a single game of fifteen so far! It means a lot to me. To top it all, there's plenty of unique reactions for optional item interactions that don't progress the game! You won't see traditional, generally accepted stuff like "Nah" or "Nothing to see here". Who does that!?

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
It is always tempting to just cop out and make an adventure game easy. People, including myself, like to feel confident about their intellectual capabilities without a good cause and would give you gleeful reviews for free. Or you can make puzzles utterly obtuse and say "it's oldschool, all point & clicks are like that". But this series of games isn't easy or obtuse at all!  They managed to make it challenging and not rage-inducing at the same time. How? The only explanation I got is that these games are ingenious and people behind them are very handsome and probably smell good. The sheer effort on display here makes me shiver. No amount of love and passion could make me work as hard as these developers do, they are actually moving the genre forward. Deponia is so good it's almost obscene!

"But wait, Magerama, you old stud, you ended up sounding like a shill! Didn't you encounter at least a few flaws?". Oh, yeah, this... I can pull a couple outta my ass if you want to... like, there was a bug, but I forgot what it was... and it turned out to be inconsequential... a couple of puzzles were not as good as other puzzles, I guess... have you noticed how different pieces of garbage fall down the screen when you roll out your inventory in the third game? So cute!

68173706.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Setting: Postapocalyptic world made of trash
Genre: Point And Click
Length: Long
[h1]Review[/h1]
Since my early days as a gamer, Point and Click genre was always present in my library. I had a lot of fun playing not well-known titles like the Reksio series. So when I had the chance to grab Deponia for free, I went for it. And what do I think of it?
[b]Plot[/b]
The setting, as interesting as it is, for most of the game it's not important. The plot is mainly focused on the shenanigans of Rufus, our main character and protagonist of the series, and the people accompanying him on his journey to Goal's heart. The game is a comedy, so you can expect a lot of pop culture references and jokes, which are often amusing and well delivered. However, the humour is mostly absurd and in Monty Pythons style, so not all people will get it.

[b]Sounds and Music[/b]
The soundtrack is mostly electronic and is quite diverse, mixing a lot of styles to fit the scenes in which it is present. Yet you can find two main themes in the soundtrack, which are metal clunking and hymnist-sounding trumpet. Apart from that, at beginning of each chapter, you get a variation of a Huzzah song from the beginning of the game, which is also quite nice.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Cartoonish and colourful, they fit perfectly the comedic tone of the game. Some of the characters may look alike, but it's not coincidental.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is fun, yet hard. It's not due to the intelligence you have to possess to do the puzzles, it's due to their abstractness. To solve them you have to think in a way Rufus is thinking, which is chaotic and sometimes illogical. I often had to use guides to get past some of the presented puzzles.

So overall Deponia is a great comedy with some abstract puzzles and an interesting piece of media.

64975650.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#289 out of 612)... it's time for Deponia: The Complete Journey.

Deponia: The Complete Journey combines the first three Deponia games into a single title. Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia. It's hard to describe the appeal of the Deponia series, but in effect, I'd say it's fans of point-and-click adventure game fans who adore the genre, don't think there are any major flaws with the usual formula, and have spent several decades wondering why, exactly, the genre lost its popularity in the mid-1990s.

I'm being snarky. I apologize. What I mean to say is simply this: these are old-school point-and-click adventure games that embrace both the best and worst aspects of the genre. The story takes you from one imaginative locale to another, and drenches every NPC interaction with so much attempted humor that the narrative lacks any semblance of emotional depth or compelling stakes. It's like a saturday morning cartoon where every time you think you might be absorbed in the action, everything grinds to a halt as the mascot character turns to the camera, cracks a smile, and delivers a profoundly lame joke with incredible confidence. That's Deponia, in a nutshell.

So if you're a fan of the genre know what to expect: lots and lots of puzzles, backtracking, and snarky hit-or-miss humor. Personally I found much of the writing to be embarrassing to listen to--but it is fully voice acted, and the voice acting is pretty solid, which I suppose has to count in Deponia's favor. Many of the puzzles also seemed (surprisingly) intuitive, and while I can't exactly say I never had to consult a guide to progress, I didn't have to keep one constantly handy, which is a pleasant departure from the usual method of play for these games.

All-in-all this is a very tepid endorsement. The Deponia games are serviceable adventure games with very solid production values and puzzle design, but with very spotty writing. They're not for everyone, but if you managed to even find this review, I suppose there's a very good chance that they might be for you.

60984407.review:
Welcome to Deponia, or as I like to call it, Modern Day Monkey Island.
It checks all the boxes in that regard.

Bumbling doofus for a protagonist, Check!

Daft slapstick comedy at every opportunity, Check!

Puzzles so frustrating and obscure you want to punch a hold through your monitor, Check!

All in the format of a classic third person point and click game. Proving the genre is still alive and well.

You follow the misadventures of Rufus, a self centred idiot who you will frequently want to punch in the face (and probably a lot more after you see all the things he does in the sewers of Deponia 3) as he tries to escape the junk-strewn planet of Deponia, accidentally uncovers a genocidal conspiracy and puts all his effort into "getting the girl" who is oh so subtly named Goal.

Needless to say, what follows is a bizarre adventure with memorable characters, hilarious dialogue and a strange platypus obsession.

What impresses me is the first game manages to wrap itself up nicely without being overly suggestive of a sequel. You rarely see that sort of thing in most AAA titles (*cough* *cough* Blazblue! *cough*) it's quite remarkable considering they actually planned it to be a trilogy back then according to the commentary. Though I couldn't bring myself to sit through it all so I turned it off. Sorry Poki.

I picked the trilogy up when it was on sale. But I can say with full confidence it's worth paying full-price for. Some of the best moments include chasing down a submarine with weaponised dolphins,
giving your arch-nemesis a wedgie on a flagpole,
ruining a date set up by Rufus's dad (who is somehow a bigger jerk than he is), 
turning a tavern into a Donkey Kong reference 
and you know that old comedy sequence of people chasing each other in and out of random doors in a single corridor? They actually made a puzzle out of that.

All of this culminates in a finale that's actually rather heart warming I'd never have thought that was possible with a speech that literally said "We are all asses!"

And as for why this is called the complete journey when Deponia Doomsday is absent from the collection, well... you'll see why when you finish the game.

55280023.review:
Deponia is a trilogy of point-and-click adventure games, which are bundled together with Deponia: The Complete Journey. The setting of the games is a world overflowing with pollution and garbage, which is fairly unique as far as video game settings go. But by no means does this make it a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Instead, the inhabitants of this world have grown accustomed to this state of life. Every aspect of their lives has adapted to these conditions, to the point that it has become a part of everyday life that everyone has accepted. Everyone except for our main protagonist, Rufus. His ultimate dream in life is to reach Elysium, a paradise where the privileged elite of society live, far above the filth of the world below. Rufus is a refreshing change of pace for video game protagonists, in that he is inherently a very flawed individual. He is snarky, egotistical, reckless, and has a habit of causing disaster wherever he goes. But the very qualities that make him such an intolerable douchebag are what makes him such a fun character, in my opinion. It was very entertaining to see him interact with the rest of the characters, who just want to live a normal life. However, this was only one of the many things that I liked about the game.

Deponia is a very enjoyable series, and I would go as far as to say that it is one of the best point-and-click adventure game franchises out there. With a charming cast of characters, wonderful art, and funny writing, it's easy to see how passionate the creators were about the game, and why you should absolutely give it a try.

But the Deponia games exceeded my expectations and might actually be the first game I've played solely on the strength of their writing rather than gameplay.

The games are, broadly speaking, about the absolutely deplorable main character being dragged kicking and screaming into doing the right thing as the stakes mount so high that even he can't ignore them. It honestly might be the only instance I've encountered where an truly unlikable character is made somewhat redeemable in a way that matters, rather than either a) remaining an asshole while we're supposed to believe that it's okay now or b) never really being an asshole in the first place and undergoing totally artificial character development. I had some real laughs at various parts of things, and while I maintain that Rufus is just horrible and have no idea what these other characters see in him, the general narratives of an asshole learning to toss aside his own pettiness for the greater good was honestly really well done.

I got this trilogy for free from Humble Bumble, and for the longest time, I never touched it... and I wish I did sooner. I found the journey throughout all three of the games to be both entertaining and horrifying at times, especially near the end with what has to be done to progress. The Radio quest part of Chapter one for instance, I don't think I would have made it through in good time if I didn't have a guide for that part, and I found it was perhaps the worst part of the whole trilogy. But aside from that, some of the humor was great, like some of the random things you can do for an achievement, or going back in certain areas leads to you ending up witnessing something else entirely, or some of the dialogue between characters which often times, showcases Rufus's insufferable personality. I'd say this game's world was pretty well done (and looks well off) for a world that's pretty much all trash now, and the people are having to live in that trash.

First things first: I love this game. But it's not perfect. It's occasionally a little too obvious that the English dialogue had been translated from another language (German). Most of the translation is superb, but that just makes those occasions where it isn't really stand out. So if you speak German, you'll probably want to play it in German. The English voice cast did a perfect job, though (aside from one or two bad line readings -- like "Why, you ARE!" when it obviously should be "Why, YOU are!" -- but that's a voice direction issue).

There were a few puzzles where I had to look up the solution. That's not too surprising with a game as big as this, but I do think the puzzle design could have been better.

This game's humor is often very different from the classic LucasArts and Sierra games, but it's usually hilarious regardless. Rufus is an even bigger jerk than characters like Guybrush Threepwood and Leisure Suit Larry, but trust me, they're going somewhere with that.

But a word of warning: the game is not at all politically correct. Most of the time I'm perfectly fine with that, but I do think the transgender character Lotti may be a bit over the line. If you're sensitive about transgender humor, you may want to avoid this game. If not, fine, go to town. Either way, it's only a small part of the game; I only remember her being present in two or three scenes in the entire trilogy.

But, all in all, I consider this game a must-play. I wouldn't say it's my #1 favorite adventure game (that'd probably be The Secret of Monkey Island), but it's certainly in my top 5 at least.

Oh, by the way, this game has a sequel called Deponia Doomsday. Don't buy it. Just buy this.

(EDIT: I hadn't played this game in a few years when I wrote this review. I'm playing through it again and I feel compelled to add that the first game of the trilogy mostly sucks. I got all the achievements, which might look like an endorsement. Unfortunately, I cannot endorse this game. This is nearly a good to excellent trilogy of point-and-click adventure games. Unfortunately, it has the most sexist plot I have ever seen in a game. Also, there is one extremely ugly racist episode near the end of the third game in the series.

THE GOOD

The games are set on the landfill world Deponia. The beautiful hand-drawn art depicts a world of rusted machinery, an endless supply of working parts for the DIY projects of its inhabitants. The setting evokes a a steampunk aesthetic combined with the post-apocalyptic. It provides a justification for  the inventory puzzles. The "Rube Goldberg-esque" contraptions required by many PAC adventures aren't  out of place here.

The main character is Rufus. He is lazy, selfish, reckless, and completely lacking in self-awareness. (He is also a kleptomaniac, which also justifies the standard behavior required in PAC adventures.) His redeeming qualities are his ambition to leave Deponia for the gleaming city in the sky Elysium (which no one else shares), and the fact that his outrageous schemes and dangerous contraptions work. While others point to Rufus's unlikability as a negative, I did not find his obnoxious personality to be a downside. He is the unsympathetic comedy protagonist, like David Brent from BBC's The Office, or Larry David on Curb Your Enthusiasm. Their unpleasant behavior deliberately create discomfort in the audience, which is supposed to be part of the fun. (The game does this well, to a point.) You control Rufus as your avatar, but you are not asked to identify with him or sympathize with him, and at several points the game acknowledges that no reasonable person would do so. Even though Rufus is lacking in self-awareness, the game isn't - the other characters call him out on his bad behavior.

I really enjoyed the soundtrack. It is unlike anything I had ever heard before. I especially enjoy the piece with chiming bells, rhythmic clanking, and warm stringed bass.

Gameplay is peppered with a ton of mini-games and self-contained puzzles, most of which were fun. I found most of them to be appropriately challenging and genuinely interesting to do. The mini-games were properly *paced* and seldom outstayed their welcome. I can't think of another point-and-click series where the mini-games were so good.

The animation, sound design, and production are polished. It is clear a lot of care and attention went into making these games. Granted, I played a re-release compilation, which had many bug fixes from the originals.

THE BAD

The bulk of the gameplay, the inventory puzzles, can't avoid the flaws common to this genre. You spend much of your time thoroughly exploring sprawling locations, pocketing everything not nailed down, then combining said items with each other or with the environment in order to pass obstacles.

It is fun to gather items and brainstorm possible uses for them before the obstacles have been identified. The most satisfying puzzles are the ones where the elements of the obstacle, and the parts that make up the solution, contain enough clues that the answer arises organically after a bit of thought. Some of the puzzles in these games were clever without being obvious.

But inventory puzzles often devolve into "moon logic" that defies rational thought. Sometimes the in-game hint system gave me a nudge in the right direction, but it was not nearly robust enough given all the bizarre combinations required.

These games don't avoid requiring you to resort to brute force, combining every item with every other item in every combination, in order to figure out what works. I don't object to this per se - I imagine Tony Stark in his lab, when he gets stuck, sticking random pieces together to see what works - but these games go out of their way to make it more time consuming and more tedious.

I mentioned the sprawling environments earlier. Each of the three games has a very long middle section with SO MANY locations, SO MANY items to pick up, SO MANY obstacles to overcome, and little to no guidance as to which piece belongs to which puzzle. These games were made around 2011 - I wonder if they were chasing after some sort of "open world" trend in game design. It does not work here. The choice to go with a open world act 2 instead of a more linear approach not only make brute forcing your way through obstacles longer and more frustrating. It is an unnecessary attempt to imply freedom in what is ultimately a linear game.

Some dialogue in the game may be repeated. Other dialogue may be heard only once. Going back for achievements revealed a few instances where a non-repeatable clue is delivered in dialogue, long before the relevant obstacle has been discovered. 

In several instances, interacting with an item produces a different result on the second or third attempt, yet there is no clue on your first (failed) attempt that another attempt will be any different. These are only discovered through brute force. 

In several cases, red herrings not only mislead, they deliberately lie to the player. Some of the information given in clues is literally false. I don't expect to be handed answers on a silver platter, but I also do not expect to second-guess whether clues provided by the game are true or not. 

All of the above are examples of fake difficulty - arbitrary decisions that only make the game longer and more frustrating. I am surprised that the quality of the inventory puzzles is so uneven. Especially since the mini-games are so good.

More bad game design - in a typical PAC adventure, you will encounter Puzzle 1, for which you will craft Solution 1. That leads to Puzzle 2, for which you put together Solution 2. Finally you face Puzzle 3, make Solution 3, and so forth. The Deponia games don't structure their puzzles in series, they put them in parallel. You face Puzzle 1, and craft Solution 1. You find it doesn't get you past the  obstacle, you are now presented with Puzzle 1.1. When you create Solution 1.1, you find you STILL haven't gotten past the obstacle. You must now get past Puzzle 1.2 with Solution 1.2.

In both cases, the designer has created the same number of puzzles and you have been tasked with the same number of solutions. But in the Deponia games, you have made so much less progress. The player feels much less rewarded, and the experience feels more tedious and frustrating.

THE UGLY

The plot of these games is deeply sexist. I am sad to say this is the most misogynistic video game I have ever played. 

The female protagonist is named Goal. She literally falls out of the sky (from the floating city Elysium to the surface of Deponia). She spends most of the first game unconscious, while the men of Deponia decide her fate. In games 2 & 3, her personality is downloaded and split into 3 parts. Each part is placed on a cartridge so Rufus can manipulate her via remote control.

One would have to go out of their way to create a female protagonist with LESS agency than Disney's "Sleeping Beauty". Apparently the designers of Deponia went to a great effort.

Even worse, late in game 3 there is a puzzle which requires Rufus to manipulate the only black woman in the game to sell herself into slavery as a literal organ grinder monkey.

The designers have denied any sexist or racist intent. I can't speak to their intent, but it is irrelevant anyway.

These games are sexist.

Game 3 has a scene that is deeply racist.

I bought these games in a cheap bundle, based on their reputation. I have enjoyed other Daedalic products. If not for the sexism and racism, this trilogy of games would get a Thumbs Up. As it is, I must give them a Thumbs Down.

50301872.review:
What en experience! Almost a flawless game. 9/10

(Skip to the pros/cons section if you want just the quick summary)

Where do I even start?
The game looks like it was the soul of the directors, as seen from the first episode that gives players the option to hear the creators thoughts throughout episode one. At first, these were cringy and not interesting at all, but once you get into the game and kinda meet with the characters, it all falls into its own place. Also its a nice touch they invited the voice actors for the two main protagonists to help Poki (creator) come a little closer to his audience.

In the start of the game we meet our playable character, Rufus, trying out another experiment of his. We get one paper, that acts as our guide for the rest of the game,and on that paper written his only task - to leave Deponia, a literal junkyard of a `state` he lives in, and travel to Elysium, a literal paradise for those who had the `resources`.Because I do not wanna spoil anything, lets just say the game takes a weird twist followed by more and more weird stuff happening. Now, I can`t say anything else about the story itself, because everything is related, yes, EVERYTHING.

Since I can`t tell you about the story itself, lets talk characters.
Every character is unique. There is no copy-pasta [spoiler] until you meet Hermes [/spoiler] and every character feels new and refreshing. Even tho the entire Deponia is just a big junkpile, every part you get to discover feels just great. The creators really tried hard to make every area you go through simple enough, yet detailed. 
[i] (Little tip for those who are getting into this game for the first time and getting stuck not knowing what to do, hold `space` to reveal interactable objects, I did not know this until episode 2, and lets just say it would have helped a lot if I knew sooner) [/i]. Also, every single object has a different comment made by the protagonist, that can even sometimes help you find the right combination for the puzzle, or you can try giving a wrong item to someone and watch the funny comments.

Speaking of jokes, there is no end to them here. Everything is full of easter eggs, [spoiler] platypus eggs to be `correct` [/spoiler] witty comments and actions. There is a good reason why the main character is called Rufus (Rufus-Doofus).

Jokes aside, game is also emotionally heavy. Cliff-hangers are made perfectly and the plot is written amazingly.
I never played a point-and-click adventure before, because I always liked more action-packed fps-s, or story-driven rpg-s and after finishing this one...I gotta be honest I`m glad I took this road. It felt like a wonderful change of pace.

Now comes the part I am sad to write, but I have to, because nothing is perfect.

Lets talk about some negatives.
The first thing is, that the game itself is not `compressed ` correctly. You might get into the game and everything will be [i] mushy [/i] like someone has drawn a picture and dropped it off on the screen, and did that 30-ish times and [i] voilà [/i], now you have a mess. The good thing here is that they added a button that fixes it in the 2nd launcher (If you have the same problem, just go fiddle a bit with it).
Glitches.
Yes, there is no game without them, but here they are kinda different that what you would expect. Sometimes the text on the character conversations can be wrong, sometimes there will be none at all. It also happened a few times that my character forgot how to walk. Sometimes even just refused to do something, even tho he needed to do it to proceed.
But, every bug here is fixed with a simple save/exit/wait for steam cloud to upload/start again.
I encountered around 10 forceful restarts during my gameplay, but never missed a single save file and/or item.

So, lets go to the end here by summarizing my thought as I just completed the full trilogy:

Pros:
+Great atmosphere and the world design
+Basic, but also well detailed level-design
+Diverse characters
+Cool item combinations you can make
+Requires you to actually think outside of the box to solve some puzzles
+Great jokes
+Amazing storytelling 
+Player interactable jokes
+Poki`s guitar (you will get this one after a while)

Cons:
-Forceful restarts might be required from time to time, but no data lost on doing so.
-Music. I know music is not is not supposed to be great in games like this, but it gets way too repetitive if you get stuck.
-Item sound effects on use are recycled from other items. Not many unique sounds.
-Animations. There are around 10-ish animations for all characters. Sub-important characters have less then 5 poses, which makes it kinda dull to look at them in the same position all the time.Also some animations are recycled as well.
-Lip-sync. same as animations, around 5-ish poses are there for talking animations.

So, to conclude:
Video- 9/10 IF the developers used a bit more time on the moving/talking animations...
Audio- 7/10 Everything is repetitive except Poki`s guitar.
Story- 10/10 Cool concept.
Characters- 10/10 Bunch of refreshments around every corner.
World design- 9/10 Really good, but some episodes seem rushed when the level design is in question.
Choices- ?/10 spoiler Do choices really matter? /spoiler

Overall, an amazing 9/10 game. 
Thank you Humble Bundle for this gem of a game!

This game is mechanically fine. It's biggest flaws in the actual gameplay department are:

1.) That occasionally a very long series of puzzles hinges on a single interact-able item which blends into the background

2.) For the above reason you'll often find objects that are available and seem useful, but are only used in a later puzzle which you have not even had the chance to see the layout of yet. 

3.) The hint system is almost entirely useless

So you might be asking: Why the negative review if the point-and-click adventure gameplay is pretty solid?

Well, let's talk about the story, and the characters, and the humor...

This game seems to THINK it's a clever parody of video game and adventure game tropes, but it's little more than another example of those same reductive tropes. 

Let's take the main female character for example: Goal. Now the fact that they named her "Goal" seems like an obvious attempt to mock the way in which games have so often treated women as objects and rewards for the hero's completion of his journey. A capable dissection of that trope would go on to have their female character be an active subversion of the cliche which is lampshaded in her name, but Deponia doesn't even come close to that. Instead Goal spends the vast majority of the trilogy either asleep, kidnapped, incapacitated, or as a helpless child. She is utterly lacking in agency. On top of that, she IS treated as an object to be won by nearly every male character she encounters, from the protagonist to the dual antagonists, to the comic-relief sidekick characters. And throughout it all, she rarely, if ever, seems upset at this lack of agency. For christ's sake she even [spoiler] falls in love with the protagonist who has no redeeming qualities[/spoiler] Now the creator commentary track will assure you "No, she's a helpless object on purpose cause that's the joke!" But you cannot just call out a cliche and then execute it beat-for-beat the same way that any non-ironic game would and pretend that you're subverting harmful tropes and speaking truth to power. 

And that's just one example of this "Say it's a joke, but play it straight" attitude in Deponia.

I don't hate these games, but I don't think I can really say they are worth playing when they are so complicit in shitty attitudes that pervade gaming.

Man, oh man. What a saga.

Some of the negative reviews have zoned in on the obnoxious protagonist Rufus, who is so by design. In fact, his unfiltered selfishness is a nice meta-commentary on the logic of adventure games, picking up/stealing objects and doing so much convoluted actions to complete your goal at whatever means. But for me, what works about Rufus is the interactions he has with the environment and the way he and the other characters play off each other. Rufus' flaws are the most apparent, but he is able to step in during the weak points of the other characters. Having such an extreme personality is what drives the game and amplifies so much of its offbeat, goofy but genuine spirit.

The actual puzzles and dynamics of the game keep a steady flow, which is key in adventure games; too often a puzzle can grind you to a halt, and while not totally free of frustration, the challenges and points of ease kept a balance that I definitely picked up on while playing. 

There are some glitchy moments: namely the game would often change the setting for one-click inventory on its own after the end of a chapter, but it didn't take me out of the game. The voice-acting is sincere, and drives home the off-beat, almost but not-quite off the wall humor. And in spite of so many jokes and wacky hijinks, a steady vein of seriousness runs underneath everything, and carries Rufus through an arc (yes, he does come around, albeit very gradually), which is what really made this wonderfully oddball adventure game one I will remember and cherish. Plus, I got 30+ hours out of it, which was me devouring the game as quick as I could, because I couldn't get enough.

Edit: I finished the first game and I have no desire to continue with the series. The main character has become too irritating, and I have no interest in seeing him succeed in his endeavors. I was hoping for a build-up to a redemption story, but save (perhaps) for a literally last-minute action everything this character does is to feed his arrogant, dumb, self-centered ego at the expense of much better people. One thing would be having to watch him behave this way, but having to play as him and being [i]forced[/i] to act like a disgusting fool despite the game mockingly waving better alternatives right in front of my face is unbearable.

I change my recommendation to negative. Original review follows.

I wish there was a "Meh" button for recommendations.

I have only 5+ hours into this 40+ hour game and it has already overstayed its welcome. I'm still in the first chapter of the entire series and I'm still going with the game because I think the world is interesting and I want to know a bit more about it, but I really don't feel much compelled to keep playing. I feel like I'm forcing myself to do it most of the time.

This is old school adventure gaming, with all its pros and cons. Gameplay is simple to pick up, but puzzles can range from mundanely easy to brain-meltingly preposterous. Many puzzles require you to put yourself in the mindset of the writer and try to read his mind so you can guess what he was thinking of rather than use logic to reach a solution, so when you solve them rather than have an "A-ha!" moment you have a "WTF?" one.

Worst, some solutions simply don't work the first time. You have to try some things more than once for your actions to have a different outcome, and in many cases there's no indication of such a thing. Calling that "poor design" is being generous. And, of course, just because you realize how to solve a puzzle it doesn't mean Rufus, the character you play as, does. That means you have to make him realize how to do certain things.

Speaking of Rufus, he's really not what I'd call a likable character. He's a self-centered, egotistic prick. Once in a while he does something genuinely good, but it's mostly out of chance or for self-gain than out of goodness. His antics are rarely over-the-top enough to be funny and most of the time they come off as just mean-spirited. His personality also clashes with the puzzle system. Since he's constantly praising his own intelligence and is unable to accept his mistakes, you really can't tell if a solution isn't working because it will never work or because he hasn't figured out yet that it will.

The game also suffers from (no pun intended) lack of polish. Some subtitles are still untranslated from the original language, for instance. Animations don't always correspond with the actions and cutscenes are twitchy and feel rushed. I don't expect perfect lip-synching in a game with a different original language, but sometimes characters speak without their mouths moving at all.

Sound design is OK for the most part. The music isn't bad, but it isn't memorable either. Voice acting is actually pretty good, but the best part of the game is unquestionably its art, which is gorgeous. The design is beautiful and makes the world visually appealing and interesting. It's a shame the humor is hit or miss, considering it's supposedly a comedy game. Most of the time it feels forced and paint-by-numbers, being either too tame or not harsh enough.

I don't feel the game is bad by any means, but it just fails to keep me engaged. I'll keep going for a while to see if it gets better, only because I like the setting, but I don't keep my hopes up. I have to recommend it at least for the art and a look at an interesting world, but be wary about the mediocre gameplay.

The first thing I want to say about Deponia is that this review is a very hesitant negative review. To be honest it isn't actually bad and I have no strong opinion on whether to recommend purchasing it or avoiding it. If it wasn't for the fact this game has relatively positive reviews I probably would have given it a thumbs up.

With that out of the way, Deponia is your standard point and click adventure game in the vein of the LucasArts and Sierra games of the past. If you are unfamiliar with those two dinosaurs then you may be more familiar with their icon games Monkey Island and Kings Quest. Your main goal in Deponia is to pick up things and rub them on other things to create more things that can be rubbed on other things. If you are luckily after rubbing one or two things out you may trigger a sponanious reaction that advances the plot. 

In between rubbing it one out you will also be tasked with random minigames puzzles that flucuate wildly in difficult and appear not to have been designed with steady difficulty progression in mind. This is partially due to the game being split into three parts (which would normally justify 3 difficulty curves for weirdos who start with the 2nd or 3rd game) but is mainly due to the games lead just doing what he wants and screw you for thinking otherwise.

While learning the mechanics of the game you will play the protagonist asshat Rufus as he constantly strives to make his way to Elisium the paradise that floats above Rufus's home planet Deponia, a wasteland made of garbage. Early on in his struggles he meets and assults an innocent Elisian woman named Goal whom he feels responsible for and attempts to bring with him to Elisium. Along your journey you will constantly be at odds with the antagonist asshat Cletus, goals current-and-for-some-odd-reason-never-previous fiancee, and a mysterious military organization known as the Organanon. You travel through a variety of unique areas that artistically fit well together such as your home town of Kuvak, the floating blackmarket, Porta Fisto (and their sewers), and an Organon blast tower. The story contains quite a few twists, many of them seem pulled from no where and have plenty of plotholes but are interesting non the less. Overall it's a long story (which is why it was split into three parts) and feels like it is way too much for one game and could easily have been left out.

One thing I really like about this game is that it includes developers commentary that has unique dialog for almost every game screen including puzzle screens. While this is a common feature in remastered games like Monkey Island, most commentaries tend to include about 5-10 minutes of dialog that is so easy to miss you would be forgiven for not knowing it was there. I also really enjoy some of the characters you meet on the way, well one of the characters, Toni. Not to go into the story too much and give away how unnessecary many parts of it are, Toni is Rufus's ex-girlfriend and host (implying Rufus is a parasite). She has known him all his life as far as we know, and has dealt with his crap the longest. She is a very pitable character and it is grativing to watch her constantly chew Rufus out. My favorite scenes also include those where harm befall Rufus.

My least favorite thing about the game is the developers commentary. If you are actually reading this you know I like developers commentary but the main developer for this game is kind of an ass. The commentary annoyingly switches context from him commenting on the games development (which I enjoy) to pretending the games is some sort of movie and having conversations with the characters about how it felt to pretend to be themselves. These pretend dialogs are excruciating, go on forever, and only help remind you how selfabsorbed the main dev Poki is. One major problem you will quickly notice during the dialogs is that no one thought to balance the audio meaning if you want to hear them you will have to constantly adjust your volume as most of it is mumbled into the microphone before the lead dev begins shouting because he thinks it's funny. The developer will also constantly remind you how he screwed his developer team over by under paying them and purposely designing indivual large scenes that he could later split into smaller scenes when he "suddenly realized" they were too big. Another frequent feature is constant songs that serve no purpose other than stroking the lead devs ego as he insists on hearing his own singing voice and terrible lyrics all the time. This is also present in regular parts of the game through self insert characters such as the hobo bard (drawn to look like the main dev, and actually somewhat works) and a gondalier (also drawn to look like the main dev) who features songs with large amounts of digital static for some reason. I'm not sure why the main dev wanted to remind us how unlikable he is at all turns but he felt he needed to and that is the main reason I decided to use a walkthrough to end this game as quickly as possible.

The dialog in the game is overall not bad however one thing you may want to be aware of is that it often includes jokes meant to appeal to people the main dev personally knows or wants to play the game (such as lets players). I'm not sure why they chose to make such specific jokes but naturally they all fall flat and look stupid if you see them even if you listen to commentary which explains them.

One thing I never though I would complain about is that the game is just way too big. It's obvious the design team had a lot of ideas and wanted to do as much as possible but the game should really have been condensed into 2 entires as there was really no need for a lot of it. But for some reason the design team is obsessed with the rule of three and decided the series needed 3 games and thus needed every bit of crap they could throw in it.

If you played the previous game parts in their seperate episodes you can rest assured that the games are mostly the same. One thing I noticed was the addition of some collectables which are never introduceds and lack highlight so the only way you will probably find them (or know they exist) is if someone tells you or if you have an seizure and just start randomly clicking everything until you click the correcy rusty saw in the background full of slightly different rusty saws. The game also features enough bug fixes where you wont have to download save games from the developers website to skip broken puzzles such as the minecart in the first game. Unfortunately the game is still awkwardly split into three parts so you can't ever view all of Rufus's diagrams (one of my favorite additions to the game) without reloading 3 different saves. Oh and they also thankfully removed the single worst idea they ever had, the grogglejug option.

While I'm also not one for *trigger warnings* I would also like to remind readers that the main developers of the game are German and lack cultural perspective from nations outside their own. While I'm not sure what will bug most people I thought I would point out a few weird things Americans will probably immediately notice. For some reason at one point in the game you need to join a cult that wears white robes and white hoods and chants about purity. I'm pretty sure it was not meant as a KKK reference, but it's pretty surprising when you see it. Another really tone deaf moment is when you sell the first and only black woman you meet in the game into indentured servitude as a monkey. I shit you not. You are required to make the first and only black woman you meet (a couple are in the cutscenes to be fair) into basic slavery where she must dance and act like a monkey in the sewers to the entertainment of a weird old white lady. I'm not sure how no one ever noticed this but it's kind of horrible, that being said she is actually pretty hot and the dance is quite sexy.

Deponia: The Complete Journey contains the first three Deponia Games (Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia) it is NOT a separate game.  I made the mistake of thinking it was a separate individual game on it own and ended up buying all three original games PLUS The Complete Journey but luckily it was during one of STEAM's massive sales and they were all super cheap.  The good thing is that it gave me a chance to compare all three games with this collection.

Since this is a collection of the first 3 games, if you actually have any of those 3 games you are probably better off just buying the other 2 individually unless you find the collection is on sale and offer a better price then it would cost to buy the other 2 games (which does happen).  If you don't have any of them I would say just buy this collection.  For the most part, there isn't anything really different between the game play on the collection vs the game play in the individual games.  Graphics are the same, sound is the same.  The biggest difference is that this collection offers "director's commentary" in the game.  The bard who sings the opening, cut-scene, and end scene parts is the in-game avatar for the Games director (I want to say Pokki is his name but it's been a while and now I'm neither sure of the spelling or the name itself).  With the director's commentary you see a circle in the upper corner with his image.  Every scene you are in (including mini-games... which he loves by-the-way) has that circle.  

You click on the circle and you can hear commentary about the game related to that scene.  Some of it is background on making the game, design, sounds, dialogue, etc... but occasionally it actually gives away hints as to how to complete something in that area.  Since it does occasionally give spoilers I'd recommend playing through the game at least once without listening to the commentary but if you're really stuck it might also be beneficial to listen to it since it could help you move forward.  Not every scene has spoilers in the commentary though.  I found the commentary to be funny and entertaining.  I had already played through the games (the individual versions with no commentary) so the spoilers were not an issue for me.  My biggest disappointment with this collection is that it feels like there should be an achievement for having listened to all the commentary but unfortunately there is not.

The only real difference is that some of the achievements.  In the individual games Almost all the achievements are available except Droggeljug from Deponia (1).  However, Deponia: The Complete Journey offers three additional achievements not available in the individual games: Story Time (Goodbye Deponia), Journey Completed (upon completing all three games), Junkyard King (Deponia (1)).  Also the droggeljug mode from Deponia (1) which is available only after playing the game through at least once, is not available (which is obviously why the achievement cannot be obtained either).

Since that pretty much sums up all the essential differences in this collection compared to the individual games the rest of this will be review of the individual games:

[u][b] DEPONIA [/b][/u]
Deponia is the first game in the series.  I had heard many people say it was a good game especially for those like me who grew up on classic Point & Click adventures like King's Quest and Monkey Island.  To be honest the whole garbage/junkyard planet theme made it seem quite unappealing to me.  I'm not really into post apocalyptic dystopian future type stuff so for a long time I just ignored this game.  After having played it I wish I had looked past that a long time ago and picked the game up sooner.  It really is a great game.  It is a point and click adventure game and it's really fun.  It's got great graphics, great characters, great audio, great voice-over quality, etc... I have very few complaints about the game.  My only real complaint is the inventory system which is sometimes difficult.  It's supposed to be on screen and you can click it to open the inventory but sometimes it randomly disappears.  If that happens you have to push "i" and it will still drop down.  Besides that though I find it randomly has trouble selecting the inventory item or drops it as your trying to use it which means you sometimes have to attempt to grab and use an inventory item several times before you can actually use it.

In this Game our Main character Rufus is leaving his ex-girlfriends home (he's been living there with her for quite some time simply mooching off of her) and he's planning on traveling to Elysium which is a utopia in the sky.  He builds himself a device to transport himself there but on his journey instead finds a damsel-in distress (Goal) who he falls in love with and tries to save accidentally getting them both dumped off the cruiser to Elysium and right back where he started but now he has to try and wake her up and then get both of them to Elysium.  Rufus... is a sort of anti-hero.  He's a real jerk who generally thinks only of himself.  He's the kind of person you hate to deal with in real life but he's a sort of lovable Jerk so he's a lot of fun to play in a game.

[u][b] CHAOS ON DEPONIA [/b][/u]
Chaos on Deponia is the Sequel to Deponia and picks up with Goal trying to warn Elysium that there are still people living on Deponia and Rufus is still hell-bent on getting himself to Elysium (and also reuniting with Goal).  Of course he mucks it up and causes problems.  Now he's damaged Goals implant and has to try and fix it... he makes it worse and now he's got to convince three Goal personalities to work with/like him while still working towards fixing her overall damaged implant.  I personally didn't really care for the 3-way split personality and having to change between them but the game is fun enough that it's not a huge drawback.  You get to explore new places in this game and meet new characters (including someone else very important to Rufuf's life who I won't give away here and spoil).  There's some fun references in the game like Cuthulu and there's A LOT of platypuses... or is it platypi?  Some parts of the game feel a little tedious having to walk back and forth for one thing but it's not too bad.  The inventory issue I mentioned in the previous game is still a problem though.

[u][b] GOODBYE DEPONIA [/b][/u]
Goodbye Deponia is the third (supposedly at the time, final conclusion) game of the series.  Rufus is still trying to get to Elysium and Goal is still trying to warn them that people are still on the surface.  People who like/help Rufus the most are starting to tire of him a little too much, his relationship with Goal is stronger but strained and he's struggling with being the good self-sacrificing guy vs. his usual jerk he is.  In this game we get a lot more background filled in to finally learn why he and Cletus look so similar and there are some emotional roller coasters game-wise too.  Many of the characters from previous games continue to pop-up in this third installment too.  Inventory is still problematic.

The main character is a complete jack***. This game is all about causing the most chaos possible and then trying to profit from it, in a vain and misguided attempt to solve problems while usually creating even more problems.

If you want a game where you actually fix problems and improve people's lives, then keep looking. If, however, you would like to play a game where the protagonist is basically a caricature of your average adventure hero, being an almost completely amoral kleptomaniac egotistic, where this is played for laughs, then this is the game for you.

The graphics and music are nice, the puzzles are usually logic (if you can get in the mindset of the PC), the story is funny and at times dramatic, and the characters are memorable.

The main drawbacks are that this is not actually the complete series. It was at the time the bundle was created, but then they released a fourth game, not included here. It should have been renamed Deponia: The Original Trilogy. Also, although the PC actions usually cross the line twice, at times they go [i]too[/i] far, such as the time where he ruins the life of a happy couple in order to basically sell them into slavery, while the PC thinks he is helping them.

If you can get past the drawbacks and just kick back and enjoy the chaos, then I recommend this game. I had a lot of fun with it. Otherwise, stay away.

Deponia: The Complete Journey is NOT the complete journey as a 4th game was released and is separate from this game. A point & click game, it features a great setting, good art and some decent music and sound. However the main character and the puzzles within in are a nasty surprise...

[b]Story - 3/10[/b]

Upon starting the game you are met with a tutorial sequence...the games form of hell and it literally is. It gets repeated everytime you start a new part. It is cleverly used in the 3rd part however. From there you meet Rufus, a character who lives with his ex-girlfriend and wanting nothing more than to leave the trash heap that is Deponia and settle in the sanctuary of Elysium. Unfortunately because of Rufus' personality he ruins a whole chunk of the story and the ending is left on a cliffhanger, which of course leads into the 4th game. This ending leaves much to be desired and no one is actually satisfied with the resolution. Rufus definitely doesn't deserve to live on Elysium.

[b]Characters - 2/10[/b]

Rufus... what an absolute d*ck. Seriously this guy's ego is so big and he literally ruins everything he touches. No wonder every character that interacts with him hates his guts including his ex girlfriend who seems like saint compared to him. How she lets him live in her house is mindblowing. He would trade his girlfriends mind for a lollipop! He makes the puzzles needlessly more complicated. He tries to redeem himself towards the end but doesn't actually. He's still the same Rufus from the start to finish.

The main heroine is either drugged, tied up or split minded. All of this is caused by Rufus! The main heroine doesn't get much to do because of this and she feels like a lackluster character for the most part.

Literally the other characters have no choice but to be reactionary to Rufus. There's one point where he basically sells off a black character into slavery as a monkey. Wtf?! That is unacceptable.

[b]Gameplay - 4/10[/b]

The puzzles in this game require a guide. They are some of the most illogical puzzles ever and it really just comes down to trial and error everything in your inventory. I guess it makes sense since you are playing as Rufus and he's an absolute moron. Oh and these puzzles get extended because Rufus messes it up even if you find the solution! Some solutions to puzzles involves turning baby dolphins into canned meat... seriously messed up.

I did however find some enjoyment doing these puzzles, especially the '+-+' one and 'Oh Organon' music sheet.

There's a bunch of humour to be found here, they are hit or miss. Most quite cringeworthy. 

The developer commentary was good and helped you understand the world of Deponia more but sometimes it could be very long to sit and listen.

I encountered a bug during my playthrough. It occurs when you are trial and error combining items. This item you combine is used later in the story and you can't uncombine it, preventing progress because you need one of the parts to be combined with something else first. 

[b]Art - 7/10[/b]

This is Deponia's strongest area, the art definitely makes you feel like you're in a trashy area with all the pipes and unstable platforms littered across the area. The characters are nicely designed and you can strike an easy comparison from people on deponia and elysium with the dark and light clothing.

[b]Soundtrack - 6/10[/b]

The music is simple yet surprisingly fits quite well. The singing from the developer is good and short enough. The voice acting is superb for the most part including the part where Rufus tries to imitate Cletus. However the music isn't mindblowing at all, you won't really remember much of the music.

[b]Overall - 4/10[/b]

As much as I enjoyed what I played, with the good art, music and sounds. The story, main character and gameplay go hand in hand and come off as a chore and a unsatisfying experience. I cannot ignore some of the despicable things the main character does. I would only play this game if it is on sale and you're looking for a point and click game to pass the time. Otherwise skip.

45410646.review:
I will give this game a small recommendation to those that like comedy, point-and-click, adventure games. The game isn’t the funniest around and isn’t exactly among the best games in its genre in my opinion, but there isn’t anything horrendous about it either.
If you are new to the genre and want to dip your toes into it, I’d personally recommend you start elsewhere. If you are a fan (and veteran) of point-and-click adventures in general and just want another one to your list, then I’d say sure pick it up. Have yourself a relaxing week or two (or more depending on your free time when you pick it up) as long as you aren’t expecting to find one of the best ones out there.

I’ll start off by going into the negatives, because I like to end on a more positive note.
[u]Negatives[/u]
[b]Illogical puzzles[/b]… Now this one technically fits the context of the game, because the main character is a narcissistic madman. But it does cause some frustration, as several solutions feel more like trial and error than proper problem solving. Usually this genre does have some type of internal logic either proper logic or “child logic”, (though admittedly most games have at least one extraordinarily silly solution), but Rufus is just mad… Often the solution is doing the most moronic thing possible intentionally.
And that leads us into the [b]cast[/b]. Rufus is a horrible protagonist, completely devoid of any charm, which usually saves other reckless and careless protagonists from coming off as horrible and selfish human beings. His lack of even the most basic human kindness and decency coupled with the attitude of self-importance and “I’m too cool for this place”, makes it damn near impossible to care about anything he does. Most of the rest of the characters are not much better, dull and forgettable, even if their designs make them somewhat physically interesting. I just couldn’t get invested in most of them, and ended up skipping a lot of dialogue, because a lot of it seemed pointless and when they didn’t interest me I just wanted to move it all along to get to where they might have me an item I needed or otherwise push me along in the puzzles.
[b]The story[/b] just doesn’t seem to fit. Saving the world, gathering friends and fighting against oppressors. Seriously? Someone who is this self-centered? How can it be that he gets friends, when he insults everyone he meets? [spoiler]Seriously he literally scratches his name into a girl’s electronic brain! And refused to clean it with a small delicate brush because that was beneath him. 
He murdered baby dolphins after being specifically told to leave them alone.
And he SHATTERED his girlfriend’s mind because he would rather have a lollipop than take the expensive material she needed for her brain surgery. DESPITE THE FACT THAT HE WASN’T THE ONE PAYING FOR IT! [/spoiler] It just really breaks any sort of immersion, even in a comedy game. Rufus isn’t a really an underdog hero type, like the story-arch seems to suggest. He is more a bumbling idiot, who falls from situation to situation without any awareness. I think he would fit such a story better, one where he is an accidental hero. Even if that is a bit of a cliché, having his enemies and maybe even the common people believe he is some sort of brilliant guy, rather than having (almost) everyone know he is a complete idiot. It kinda takes the punch out of a lot of jokes, when both we and the characters knows Rufus is going something stupid… again… and again… and again. I mean no one really gets surprised by it…


The comedy is more mixed… A bit of it works, the vast majority of it doesn’t. Which is in large parts due to the main character, and the context of the story. Many jokes rely on slapstick. While seeing Rufus get hurt the first time is satisfactory, it quickly loses its punch, because he hurts everyone around him too… And he is not a dignified character, seeing a clear loser being humiliated and hurt just isn’t that funny. Some jokes just aren’t really set up properly to be fun. [spoiler]Like the big masculine hairy guy turns out to have been soft and girly as a kid… But by then we had already seen Rufus walk all over him at multiple occasions. We had seen him with an explosive passionate girl, who almost killed him and who was clearly more in charge in their relationship. And he generally had a kind and gentle demeanor… So the joke didn’t really have any staying power, since he wasn’t the ideal macho man anyway.[/spoiler] Of course some of the jokes still work, and are amusing enough that you don’t give up on the game entirely. 

[u]Positives[/u]
There are two “characters” that I really enjoyed [b]Toni and Spunky Goal[/b]. [spoiler]Toni because she really mirrors my emotions towards Rufus. The horrible human-waste’s ex-girlfriend, she is tired of his freeloading behavior and shitty attitude and is a rather cynical lady, who clearly has a heart of fucking gold in there since she hasn’t kicked the bum out or killed him despite the horrible psychological torment he has put her and her loved ones through. I’d have loved for her to be a secondary playable protagonist to balance out Rufus, but sadly that wouldn’t fit the story. Still I enjoyed the brief moments with her. Spunky Goal, while just one of Goal’s personalities after Rufus shattered her mind for a lollipop, is the other character I truly enjoyed. Mostly because of the contrast between her and the actual Goal, who is more of a classic damsel in distress most of the time (and a pretty pathetic one at that, when you fall for a guy like Rufus), Spunky Goal however is a really fun contrast. An over the top tough girl, ready to beat your little boy butt for looking at her funny, inside the body of such a feminine little body. I appreciated her threatening Rufus.[/spoiler]
[b]The visuals[/b] I enjoyed the overall cartoony style of it, the background, the looks of the characters. I think that is one of the strong points of the game.
[b]The setting and world[/b] the setting is nice and simple, a planet that is overrun with junk all around, with the humans living there having adapted to the horrible environment, and an almost dreamlike city floating above their heads, which no one can get to. Simple, but with room for variations on the locations between the different games.

43554160.review:
Despite moments of brilliance and enough minigames to impress a Hasbro executive, there are a few critical problems with Deponia that are never addressed. As you may know, you're buying three games here. The first and especially the last are by far the strongest in terms of story and puzzles, while the second (middle) entry is fairly weak. It's going to sound like I'm being very hard on the game, but I actually like it quite a bit. It just has some core problems in writing and game design that are never addressed, even after 3 games. I'll be talking about story flaws and game design, but it will be worded in such a way that spoilers are avoided. 

The first problem is the story. The conceit of the adventure, the end goal that’s always hanging over Rufus’ head… it doesn’t make any sense. The protagonist’s only motivation is to reach to a place called Elysium. It is literally a glowing castle floating over the planet. Everyone Rufus meets tells him this is an impossible and foolish task. We never, ever learn why people think it’s impossible to reach Elysium. 

This problem is especially prevalent in the first 1/3 of the game because we learn there are multiple places on the planet where an ordinary cable car connects the ground to Elysium. Allegedly, the problem is that you need “ascension codes.” This doesn’t matter, of course, because there’s no reason on Deponia why someone couldn’t just make a second cable car. Everyone tells Rufus his goal is impossible or even acts like Elysium is a myth when there are literally cables connecting Deponia to the massive glowing castle in the sky. There is no reason given why the lower ascension station shouldn’t be a thriving city, rather than an abandoned ruin. 

Things only get worse once we learn the Elysian’s motivations. This problem is only compounded when the secondary antagonist essentially kidnaps someone to take back to Elysium, even showing off his prisoner, when it has been established on numerous occasions that the tertiary antagonist and Big Bad don’t want any Elysians to know about Deponians for various reasons. It seemingly throws a big fat rusty wrench into everything the game has been trying to tell us because nothing about Elysium in the game all about reaching Elysium and dealing with Elysian politics makes any sense. 

Then there’s the puzzles.  In practice, there are only four puzzles (not counting the diverse and interesting minigames) in the whole Deponia series. The way they are presented is generally enjoyable. Rather than gatekeeping (layered fetch quests to open next area) most of Deponia’s puzzles push the story forward and have rippling consequences. That’s good, but it doesn’t excuse that the solutions typically are…
1.	Trick person into doing something
2.	Analyze and modify a Rube Goldberg machine 
3.	Talk to someone until they do something for you 
4.	Realize item won’t work until its combined with another item. Then place new item in the same place. 

These puzzles get complicated awfully quickly and don’t always make a lot of sense. For example, you’re trying to make a guy trip on a banana peel, but he doesn't slip on it correctly. So you go on an extremely lengthy and convoluted side mission to straighten a banana for no reason. The result is that nothing different happens with the banana, but a different cutscene plays. Rufus could have solved the puzzle on his own all along, but we just wasted 45 minutes doing a stupid side puzzle that has no echos on the story.  

Every puzzle has multiple, multiple steps because the protagonist, Rufus, is a blithering idiot. Rufus is so bad, the entire second part of the trilogy could be completely ignored if Rufus acted like an actual person instead of a one-note cartoon character. The problem then is that the events at the start of the second game create a butterfly effect that makes the events of the third game almost unrecognizable. 

Many puzzles also simply rely on repetition. It may seem you’re out of options until you do the same thing over and over and over. One part forces Rufus to knock on a door three times under specific conditions to proceed. If you didn’t know that, it would quickly seem you were out of options. 

It’s because of moments like the door puzzle and the banana puzzle that it appears the writers may have been overindulgent. Many, many times while playing this game I got up in the middle of a conversation to go to the bathroom and when I came back the characters were still talking; the dialogue box still hadn’t opened. Characters, especially the soothsayer, drone on and on without saying anything of comedic or character value. Yes, we get it.  Rufus is an egomaniac. 

Rufus’ dialogue, even with familiar characters, constantly has to remind us of his single character trait over and over and over again. This is acceptable in the first chapter because they try to show Rufus has grown at the start of the second chapter. But the entire second game is caused by the fact that Rufus hasn’t grown even a little bit. By the start of the third game, he’s as bad as he was at the very start of the first game in spite of everything he’s done over the past 10 hours. It’s absolutely maddening to watch character progression that consistently takes one step forward and three steps back. 

More than anything this is FRUSTRATING when it comes to Rufus speaking to the other protagonist. She constantly asks him very simple questions which you can’t answer like a rational person. Rufus constantly lies about lying. He won’t give a straight answer. Whenever he’s confronted and simply asked to explain his side of the story, the writers just have him uncontrollably babbling “but I’m the good guy!” without a single ounce of context every. single. time. this happens. It’s an entire game based around the idiot ball trope. 

If juggling the idiot ball, repeating puzzles, and watching hours of overindulgent humor tickles your fancy, by all means buy the Deponia trilogy. If you want character growth, a comprehensible story, and an engaging antagonist, go play Grim Fandango.

38989921.review:
'Deponia: The Complete Journey' is a point-and-click adventure game compilation that consists of the first three games of the series: 'Deponia', 'Chaos on Deponia', and 'Goodbye Deponia'. Together, they tell the story of Rufus' quest to leave garbage-filled surface of Deponia for the idyllic floating town of Elysium.

'D:TCJ' is the best way to experience the grand scope and epic nature of Rufus' journey. The pacing of each of the three games is somewhat uneven, with overly long middle sections that seem to go nowhere. Thankfully, it is in these middle sections that we find the more interesting puzzles and fun mini games, which help you stay motivated. All three games, when played back to back in 'D:TCJ', present a clearer story and character arcs.

One of the most captivating aspects of 'D:TCJ' is the beautifully drawn characters and locales. The appealing art design, and the detail with which the characters and locations are realized, give the recent Remastered releases of LucasArts games a run for their money. The trash-covered planet of Deponia is an imaginative and visually stunning one, which was surprising to me at first given that it is covered with garbage. However, Deponia is a lot more lively and vibrant than one would imagine.

The English voice acting in 'D:TCJ' is also spot-on, adding personality to the interesting characters. Rufus is particularly unique among adventure game heroes. Whereas main characters of popular adventure games can be heroic, quirky, clumsy, or perhaps have their share of foibles, Rufus is just not (very) likeable and not even an anti-hero at all, for he is egotistic, narcissistic, and self-centred. And yet, he is captivating as a playable character, in part due to the great voice acting by Kerry Shales. Even when reasons for Rufus' faults are revealed and explained, it feels abrupt and a bit like damage control. You will definitely find divisive opinions on whether or not Rufus is a good main character in an adventure game.

You will also find divisive opinions on the jokes in 'D:TCJ'. Some people find them funny, some not. Personally, I find the game amusing -- not very funny, but entertaining enough. This could be due to the funny bits being lost in translation from the original German (and the game is very self-aware of it), or it could be simply due to what people find funny. However, I did find some scenarios, jokes and characters depiction off-putting, sexist, and culturally insensitive. Whether or not you can overlook these flaws is up to you.

However, I can definitively say that the puzzles in this game are fun. Some are challenging, some require some form of moon logic, and some tickle your brain just enough. Despite the length of the game (I easily clocked in over 24 hours of gaming time in total despite what my stats say because I played parts of the game offline), there is a good variety of puzzles to keep gameplay fresh. The art and the puzzles are definitely highlights of 'D:TCJ', and I very much enjoyed the game in spite of the flaws I previously mentioned.

'D:TCJ' is a great adventure game. It embodies both strengths and weaknesses of great adventure games that came before. Questionable quality of jokes and content aside, it definitely deserves the accolades that it received. It is a must-play for anyone who enjoys point-and-click adventure games.

P.S.: For achievement seekers like I, you will find some achievements for 'D:TCJ' very difficult to get, let alone figure out what they are about. mishalunchbox wrote fantastic walkthroughs and [URL=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=875459798]achievement guides[/URL] that you should definitely consult if you are interested in getting all achievements.
