37828774.review:
"Being careful is for people who can't handle surprises."

Any classical point-and-click adventure at its core is a relatively linear set puzzles that tells you a story when you solve it. The premise of this story is simple: a young man Rufus wants to leave his home world Deponia. That is understandable, because Deponia is a junkyard of planetary proportions. There is, however, one twist to the classical hero's journey. Apparently, our 'hero' is a s--tstain on humanity! Surprising? Maybe. But let's have a little thought experiment. Say, you've encountered one of the three playable characters of the LucasArts classic "Day of the Tentacle" in person. What would you say about them? Right, they are utter maniacs! Dangerous, unpredictable, with tendency to pilfer every object that isn't screwed tight to the surface it rests upon. And if it is screwed tight, they will just come back with a screwdriver. Then they will recombine the stolen commodities in bizarre ways and you better run when they put their mccguyvering to use.

Our protagonist Rufus is the logical conclusion to this line of thinking. Rufus doesn't pretend to be a good guy. Everything in the world will serve his goal to leave his garbage-riddled home Deponia and reach almost mythical Elysium. Rufus will leave nothing but chaos and destruction behind, and you, the player, will guide him through the challenges. But perhaps exactly because Rufus is so unabashedly self-absorbed, in the crucial moment when he does something indisputably selfless, you will be truly touched. So be reckless, blast your way through the junkyard that is Deponia, enjoy the story loaded with witty, sarcastic, and sometimes even dark humour, and in the end Rufus may pleasantly surprise you.

10/10, I love fixing junkyard presses.

Adventure games tell a story which, when told, has no reason to be told again - you know what happens. So they have only one, big shot, and they've got to make it count. Deponia's bullet into my heart is here to stay.
A game that made me scratch my head for ingenious solutions, laugh it off over puns, jokes and references, and hold it in shock over the successive twists.

Injected with heavy doses of satire and never allowing you to take it seriously, the game paves an unlikely way to your brain, where it exposes different sides, personas and behaviors of society - but it abstains from any judgement, and allows for a cooled-off, conscious overview. 
Its blatant anti-hero pierces his way into your heart, turning from the most loathed egomaniac to the most improbable genious (an inspector Clouseau of sorts) and unexpectably lovable companion - to the point that his misses, sacrifices and heartbreak hurt your very feelings. The Deponia series is a classic point-and-click adventure where you control Rufus, a young man living on the planet of Deponia, and trying to get to the idylic floating city of Elysium.

You talk to characters to learn about the story and figure out what you need to do to progress, as well as pick-up, combine, and use items to solve problems. The series also features mini-games, though if that isn't your thing or you just get frustrated with them, there is the Skip option which auto-solves them for you so you can continue.

It's a funny game that had me laughing out loud more than once. There were a few occasions where the solutions for puzzles were a bit out of left-field, but they are, for the most part, fairly solid. The only actual gameplay issue I had was the fact that, for some reason, it didn't always like to let me select items in my inventory. For whatever reason, I would sometimes need to click an item multiple times to select it. Thankfully, that was only an issue for the earlier parts of the series. 

Here's the basic premise of the story:
Deponia is a planet whose inhabitants generated so much garbage over time that the world is literally covered in it. Things are so bad for Deponia that finding clean water is like striking oil or discovering a gold mine. At some point in Deponia's history, the upper-crust elite built Elysium for themselves, an idylic city floating way above the trash-heaps, and conected to Deponia only by a single tether, which is guarded and patrolled by their military servants known as the Organon. Rufus, a citizen of Deponia, has long dreamed of escaping their garbage-heap of a planet and living in the lap of luxury in Elysium. Unfortunately for him, and everyone around him, Rufus, while remarkably clever in his own crazy way, is too lazy and conceited to bother with such things like considering the potential consequences of his actions or myriad ways in which his inane schemes could go wrong. As a result, he's known as a walking disaster, and is a social pariah. (Not that his ego would let him consider that he's anything but the greatest person on Deponia.) Things, however, take a different turn when Rufus comes across an Elysian woman named Goal, and realizes that helping her return to Elysium may be his own ticket in. Thus begins his adventure.

One of the more interesting things about Deponia is Rufus himself. Unlike most "heroes" he is only tolerated at best, and with good reason. He's careless, egotistical, and his main motivation is "how will this help ME?" This fact is often lampshaded by his friends as they groan in exasperation and wonder what spectacular way he'll screw things up this time. However, as terrible as Rufus can be, it also helps to highlight his good points. He may be an egotistical, self-serving jerkass, but that doesn't mean he doesn't care. In fact, there are several points where his zany schemes may actually have worked out if he hadn't sabotaged them himself to save his friends. (Of course, they wouldn't have been in danger if not for him, but still...) Rufus is a flawed character, a BADLY flawed character, but one can't help but root for him in the end. 

The rest of the other characters, both major and minor, play pretty well off the ego-centric Rufus, and the overall story and progression of the games is interesting, exciting, and amusing. If you're looking for a wacky point-and-click adventure that's laugh-out-loud funny, intriguing, and more than a little insane, I'd highly recommend Deponia.

Would recommend to: Monkey Island fans specifically or fans of LucasArts or Sierra adventure games in general, who don't mind having to google up a working save file. I highly reccomend buying all three in one bundle because if you buy just one you'll end up buying the next one anyway. Trust me.

the characters are some of the most likeable I've seen, and you're with all of them so long you just [i]have[/i] to love them by the end. it's hard to pick favorites, but personally mine would have to be Cletus. honestly, i think that the characters and the dialogue are the best part of the game.
